markdown:
Find “rhodo.art.q20.int.PE.reads” and add this set of paired-end reads to your Narrative by mousing over it and clicking the Add button that appears at its left.
Exit the Data Browser by clicking either the Close button at the bottom right of the browser window or the arrow at the top of the Data Panel. (Note that you also can close the Data Browser by clicking anywhere in the main Narrative panel in the center.)

!null(http://kbase.us/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/AssembleAnnotate10.png)

After a moment your Data Panel will update to show the dataset that you just added.
Don’t be concerned that there is only one data object for the paired-end reads. In KBase, the two original paired-end read files get combined into a single data object.

Suggested Replacements:
The following replacement apps might help and are available in the Apps menu:
  1. insert_set_of_genomes_into_species_tree_generic
    • Insert Genome Into Species Tree
  2. build_genome_set_from_tree_generic
    • Build Genome Set From Tree

## Step 2. Add and run the app

Now that you have your input data, you can add the Assemble and Annotate Microbial Genome app to your Narrative. Take a closer look at the Apps & Methods Panel directly below your data. In KBase, apps and methods are the same thing except that an app consists of more than one method. In this case, we are using a two-step app.
You can search for apps or methods using the search box at the top of the Apps & Methods Panel or just scroll until you find the one you want. Find the Assemble and Annotate Microbial Genome app and click on its name (or icon) to add it as a new cell in the main Narrative panel.

markdown:
Find “rhodo.art.q20.int.PE.reads” and add this set of paired-end reads to your Narrative by mousing over it and clicking the Add button that appears at its left.
Exit the Data Browser by clicking either the Close button at the bottom right of the browser window or the arrow at the top of the Data Panel. (Note that you also can close the Data Browser by clicking anywhere in the main Narrative panel in the center.)

!null(http://kbase.us/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/AssembleAnnotate10.png)

After a moment your Data Panel will update to show the dataset that you just added.
Don’t be concerned that there is only one data object for the paired-end reads. In KBase, the two original paired-end read files get combined into a single data object.

Insert Genomes into Species Tree (multi-step app)
Obsolete App!
Sorry, this app is obsolete and can no longer function. But don't worry! Any results produced by running this app have been retained.
Parameters:
  1. insert_set_of_genomes_into_species_tree_generic
    • param2 -
    • param1 - 100
    • param0 - [u'']
  2. build_genome_set_from_tree_generic
    • param1 -
    • param0 -

Suggested Replacements:
The following replacement apps might help and are available in the Apps menu:
  1. insert_set_of_genomes_into_species_tree_generic
    • Insert Genome Into Species Tree
  2. build_genome_set_from_tree_generic
    • Build Genome Set From Tree

## Step 2. Add and run the app

Now that you have your input data, you can add the Assemble and Annotate Microbial Genome app to your Narrative. Take a closer look at the Apps & Methods Panel directly below your data. In KBase, apps and methods are the same thing except that an app consists of more than one method. In this case, we are using a two-step app.
You can search for apps or methods using the search box at the top of the Apps & Methods Panel or just scroll until you find the one you want. Find the Assemble and Annotate Microbial Genome app and click on its name (or icon) to add it as a new cell in the main Narrative panel.

markdown:
# Notes

## Cell Improvements

Cell mechanics are currently a little wonky.

- bugs
  - cell contents shift as they are selected
  - menu bottom will hide under container bottom if overlap
  - hard to see cells, since they don't have boundaries
  - the cell prompt causes the code cells to shift over (it needs a hard width)
- todo
  - icon not displayed for new app cell -- looks like the toolbar and app contents are rendered before the cell is built, so the prompt is not available.
  - method cell does not start with toolbar area displayed.
  
  
## Review of Widgets

### Analyze 

use the Analayze tab, ensure all buttons work, panels open close

### Analyze > Data

### Analyze > Apps & Methods

# Bugs

## Analyze/Data 

- if data in panel, then delete it, it still appears in the data panel.
- also, if add data, the data panel is not updated.
  
- Data Flyout Panel
  - try to add public data gives error
  
```
Error: Object kb|g.1427 cannot be accessed: User eapearson may not read workspace KBasePublicGenomesV5
```
  - error is persistent -- even switching data tabs it stays there
  - even closing and re-opening the data tab, it stays there.
 
- Back to the sidebar data panel, the filter doesn't work very well. It does not always show filtered results, even if it says it has the data, and it does not actually reset to show all when show all is selected.

- The big red plus button can obscure functional parts of the last data item. E.g. the ... menu, as well as informational bits (e.g. the metadata that pops up from ...).
- on the last data item, when expand the item via the ..., it will open up below the container, so that the container needs to be scrolled up to access it.

- Can't drag data item to bottom of narrative

- data widgets don't render a loading icon while loading.

- drop zone for data widgets is not shown visually, it is a guess as to where it will appear.

- Dragged data object goes "under" many elements in the narrative view

- sometimes the "drag onto narrative -->" tooltip persists after the item has been left, and sometimes gets in the way.

- the links to data items should not be tooltips, it provides no useful information.

- clicking the title to place in narrative is not intuitive, i would expect the title to pop up a description or something. A simple arrow on the right hand side would be better.

## Apps & Methods

- right side of filter is cut off by the X button
- filtering is generall weird and non-intuitive.
- no drag/drop, which is weird given that the data objects are draggable. 
- should show how many items are displayed in the filter (currently only shows how many are NOT displayed!)

- an output name may be pre-populated by existing data objects. whether you want to select one or not, one WILL be selected and inserted into the field. 

## Narrative Editor / Viewer

- vertical scroll when not necessary.
- no positive feedback that saving is in progress, subtle message when the save has succeeded.
- this comes into play if you want to save and then reload ... reload generates an warning if save has not finished, but it is hard to know when save has finished
- save button should be enabled when save is valid (that is, anything changed.)
- save message is "checkpoint created 00:00:00"
  - time is not valid
  - "checkpoint" does not match "save" nor "version"
  - the message disappears too quickly
  
- there should be narrative info buttons on the main document view, at least as functional as the ones on the narrative list. perhaps an "info" button which pops up info about this narrative, including metadata, save history/versions, authorship, sharing, etc.

- when adding new widgets via the markdown or code round buttons at the bottom right, it is unclear where they are placed. They are not highlighted.

- the insert cell above/below menu option in the toolbar is not very useful. It only adds a markdown cell. Perhaps it could be called "add markdown above/below" but that seems to be rather limited utility.

## App Widgets

- overall, it looks like there are cases in which the ipython keyboard trapping is not being handled. I added a widget, Assemble and Annotate, could select reads, but not enter output, then when I pressed the "d" key the cell was deleted.

- entry into select2 dropdown/entry combo is really weird. The entry area is below the normal input box.

- advanced params is weird. 
    - The second column repeats the labels of the first
    - info tooltips repeat the same thing again
    - long labels from first column overlap the second, they don't wrap
    
- after inputing paramters, but before running, when saving the narrative, the parameters are not saved 

## Markdown Widget

- the placeholder text "Type _Markdown_ and LaTeX: $\\alpha^2$" should be present as markdown when double click.
- or the placeholder text should be removed, what purpose does it really serve?

# Here Bugs

This is for recording bugs in new things that I've introduced

## Not working right

- markdown cell shows both edit and preview (input and output) when entering edit mode (dblclick) after the cell has been closed and then re-opened.

- markdown cells do not get an icon when first opened in a narrative. they do when the markdown cell is added, and they do after it is edited and rendered. this has to do with the icon being shown in the prompt area, which is not in the cell toolbar, and is not necessarily available when the markdown is first rendered, which sends the event to the toolbar, which also must have been rendered. of course, best would be if the entire framework were rendered, and then each widget given the go signal. still, i can surely work aroud this, just haven't done it yet. perhaps will store the title, icon, and other state shared between these cell features in the cell js object properties (right now using the cell node because when I started this it wasn't clear how or if the cell js object was propagated through to the constructors etc.)

- run and error icons don't work correctly for app and method cells.

- code cells don't collapse or have a title

## Could be better

- the insert cell above/below on the gear icon are not all that useful, because only inserts markdown.

- collapse all with option + click and/or ctrl + click. Look for best practices for this (e.g. maybe better if there were a button on the notebook toolbar to do this instead.

- when saving, the state of the cell should be better preserved. E.g. if a Markdown cell is being edited, it would be best to have it opened as such (and even nice if the cursor were positioned correctly.)

## More Bugs

- inserting a new cell does not select the new cell
- inserting or moving a cell does not result in activated buttons


## View Mode
- should turn off border, celltoolbar, open all cells
# Hello, I'm a Markdown Cell

markdown:
# Microbial Metabolic Model Reconstruction and Analysis

Janaka's version

----
A key scientific objective of KBase’s Microbes team is to reconstruct and predict metabolic and transcriptional regulatory networks to facilitate the manipulation of microbial function (for example, to optimize biofuel products). This tutorial highlights the tools in KBase that support the reconstruction and analysis of genome-scale metabolic models from genome sequence data.

> NOTE (to users): This tutorial is read-only. It shows the results of the steps. If you'd like to run the steps yourself--and maybe change some of the parameters or input your own data--you will need to make your own copy of it. Click the blue “Copy Narrative” button at the top right of the screen. This will copy the Narrative that you are currently viewing to your account, and you should see the new copy appear at the top of “My Narratives”. The copy is now yours–-you can open it, run it, edit it, and even share it with others. For more information, please see the [Narrative User Guide](http://kbase.us/narrative-guide/access-and-copy-narratives/).

The steps shown in this tutorial are: ## 1. Load a Genome into your Narrative You can upload your own data to KBase to analyze it, but for demonstration purposes in this tutorial, we’ll start by choosing a data object—-a genome—-that's already in KBase and adding it to our Narrative. To add the example genome, first click the Add Data (or red “+”) button in the Data Panel on the left of your screen. (If you don’t see this button, make sure you have the Analyze tab selected.) The Data Browser will slide out, with tabs that show several data sources. Select the Public tab and search for Escherichia coli K12. Find the genome called "Escherichia_coli_K12" and add it to your Narrative by hovering your cursor over it and clicking the Add button that appears at its left. _(I will update this screenshot)_ !null(http://kbase.us/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/AssembleAnnotate10.png) Exit the Data Browser by clicking either the Close button at the bottom right of the browser window or the arrow at the top of the Data Panel. (Note that you also can close the Data Browser by clicking anywhere in the main Narrative panel in the center.) After a moment your Data Panel will update to show the dataset that you just added.

## 2. What's in your Genome object?
You can click on the Shewanella_oneidensis_MR-1 genome object in your Data panel to see a genome viewer (see below).

If you click on the name of the genome at the top of the viewer (Shewanella_oneidensis_MR-1), a Landing Page (also called Detail Page) for that genome will open in a new browser tab.

-- short explantion of each tab (from the genome man page/tutorial)

## 3. Reconstruction of Metabolic Model and Gapfill in Complete Media

KBase’s toolkit includes apps and methods for reconstruction, curation, reconciliation, and analysis of metabolic models. This section and the sections that follow explore some of that functionality.

Now that you’ve loaded a genome object into the narrative, you can build an initial draft metabolic model based on the gene annotations in your genome object.

Go to the APPS & METHODS panel at the left. (If you don't see it, make sure you're looking at the "Analyze" tab.)

In KBase, apps and methods are the same thing except that an app consists of more than one method. You can search for apps or methods using the search box at the top of the Apps & Methods Panel (click the magnifying glass), or just scroll until you find the one you want. Find the "Build Metabolic Model" method and click on its name (or icon) to add it as a new step in your Narrative.

Now you need to fill in the fields for the method. Choose the E. coli genome you loaded, and make up a name for the model that will be created. Then click the "Run" button at the bottom of the method cell to start building the model.

markdown:
# Microbial Metabolic Model Reconstruction and Analysis

Janaka's version

----
A key scientific objective of KBase’s Microbes team is to reconstruct and predict metabolic and transcriptional regulatory networks to facilitate the manipulation of microbial function (for example, to optimize biofuel products). This tutorial highlights the tools in KBase that support the reconstruction and analysis of genome-scale metabolic models from genome sequence data.

> NOTE (to users): This tutorial is read-only. It shows the results of the steps. If you'd like to run the steps yourself--and maybe change some of the parameters or input your own data--you will need to make your own copy of it. Click the blue “Copy Narrative” button at the top right of the screen. This will copy the Narrative that you are currently viewing to your account, and you should see the new copy appear at the top of “My Narratives”. The copy is now yours–-you can open it, run it, edit it, and even share it with others. For more information, please see the [Narrative User Guide](http://kbase.us/narrative-guide/access-and-copy-narratives/).

The steps shown in this tutorial are: ## 1. Load a Genome into your Narrative You can upload your own data to KBase to analyze it, but for demonstration purposes in this tutorial, we’ll start by choosing a data object—-a genome—-that's already in KBase and adding it to our Narrative. markdown:
# Narrative Sprint - To CI (and Beyond!)

This Narrative document is being used to track my progress with this sprint, and to collect thoughts about improvements and enhancements...

# Notes

Blah... bleeh

# Must Fixes

- ~~Toolbar is not always in selected state when cell select - nail down the cases and fix.~~
  - _okay, one use case is when a cell is deleted, and the previous cell is selected._
  - _Fixed: traced the deletion call from kbase's kbaseNarrativeWorkspace, to notebook.js, which takes care of selecting the appropriate cell through cell.select. So extended that method in custom.js so that we can emit an event 'selected.cell' directly to the cell. This event is already set up to do the right thing._ 
  - _It works, and also allowed the removeal of the same event from kbaseNarrative from within the 'select.Cell' handler. It appears that select.Cell is not always called for cell selection within jupyter, instead the direct select method is used, which does not emit an event_
- main buttons disappear after a while after network connection loss (and failed save... but need more testing)
- weird error message upon save of narrative if no network connection (for local dev install, but simulates workspace loss for a narrative?)

## Navbar
- kernel > About Jupyter does nothing.
- login button does not show gravatar
- login button does not show user's name or username
- login dropdown should disappear if user clicks away; right now it only does so if user clicks again

## Login

Login weirdness:

sign out ends up on 404: http://localhost:8888, without login button

can sign in at http://localhost:8888/narrative/tree, which has the sign in button

after login on the tree page, it is not refreshed

if sign out with data filled in, get "Are you sure you want to leave this page? Unsaved changes will be lost" Even if one selects "Saty on page", the logout event proceeds and the narrative "looks" as before, but ...
- it should not be even visible if the user is logged out (close window, redirect, refresh, anything)
- not just narrative, but menu buttons stay there and initiall "work", but will not actually do what you want them to. E.g. share just hangs; kernel menu still works even without auth

if try to save "Narrative savew failed!" with no message, and just OK button; also hyellow message in narrative shows "You do not have permission to view the narrative with id XXX".

login works, and back to normal.

possible to have jupyter keyboard commands leak through in this case - fresh narrative view, make changes, logout out, click stay on page, try to log back in again -- now keystrokes go to ipython and start doing dark magic to one's narrative, and do not appear in the log in form.



## Markdown
- ~~Markdown cell state gets messed up (input AND output) upon going into edit mode.~~
- ~~double clicking should open up and put into edit mode. right now just puts into edit mode without opening, weird...~~
  - _so now it toggles open if it was closed to start with, does nothing additional with edit mode._
  - _next is to hide the output when going into edit mode. my guess is that the toggling gets reversed with the open/close, and the logic for the editor is to simply toggle the output area -- there is not input/output state stored in cell?_
  - _okay, that is now fixed. It was due to the jquery hide()/show() -- show ends up leaving display="block" on the element, even if it was not set originally. The new method adds display="none" and then removes the display style for showing. Also key to this is the method used by the markdown editor to swap the editor and rendered -- it uses a class on the cell (rendered/unrendered) to control the visilibity of the editor/rendered_
  
- exiting from edit mode is annoying. 
  - When blurring on the markdown edit field, it just closes. This makes sense when clicking to another narrative element (perhaps), but not when just blurring out to another app. If one is writing, and needs to activate other windows, etc. as part of that process, it is plain annoying to have the editor close down, lose cursor position, etc.
  
## Code Cells

- when opening a code cell, the widget area prompt is displayed. This is surely another case of the toggle method employed either being too crude or simply out of sync with the way that the notebook hides/shows code cell elements

## Concurrent Usage

There needs to be a better story for concurrent usage of a narrative. As it is, concurrent saves are allowed, and they do not "overwrite" but just will interleave changes in the versions; it does "appear" that there has been overwriting...
So, perhaps better detection of

# Nice to Have

- nicer save / savepoint feedback
- silly hover paragraph icon for markdown cells -- built into notebook, but why? 
- double click expands closed cells,
- remove extraneous items from kernel menu
- "About this Narrative" button/menu item and pop up dialog (or maybe even a cell?) populated with useful info about the narrative - created, last saved, versions, copies...
- narrative preferences: autosave, mode (basic/advanced), 
- run button in cell toolbar for code, app, method cells.
- help! we need more integrated help. For starters:
  - cell specific help - markdown, code cells
  - data cells should at least have (some of the) tools available in the data panel
  - app and method cells could open up a modal narrative method store
- better messaging experience -
   - consistent location for messages
   - better language
   - longer persistence, or long persistence with ability to close
   - message log (at least for the narrative session) with ability to clear, or expand to get more info or help.
   - this could be on the expanded left nav area
- "reset" or "normalize" for app/method cells. The jupyter markdown styling can interfere with widget styling, which causes otherwise good people to put in place hacks to override. (kb output cell something or other). Rather, the style reset should be at the top level, and any specific styling (for input, output, etc) within an app/method cell should be provided by the widget developer (or perhaps even there the app/method cell should provide this...)

# Cool!

- drag and drop cells
- drag and drop apps and methods
- binding of cells to each other (move, d&d, delete, etc.)
- drag and drop code cell and markdown cell 
- basic and advanced mode. Advanced mode would unlock features like code cell icon, kernel menu, and perhaps other ipython stuff
- more metrics: narrative opens, narrative runs, ...

# Ideas / Maybe

Move Apps and Methods into own panel, remove Narratives, make a better dashboard, or a slide out panel for narratives. Narratives is not really a useul tool to have within a narrative, compared to the primary tools of the object browser, app & method browser, and jobs. Also, the narrative browser should have more space -- titles often wrap, there should be search.

Move New Narrative to the horizontal menu (does not exist yet) or simply make a navbar button (for copy too)

Remove the annoying circle buttons at the bottom of the narrative. It is weird to have that be the way to add code and markdown cells, yet data viewers and apps/methods are added from the left side.

Remove the big + circle button from data. It is confusing, since there is already a way to pull up the data panel, and gets in the way.

While on the subject of the left area, perhaps there is a better way to provide "tabs". The horizontal space is very limited, and it may that there are more than major functions to expose. 

For example, what about a narrative summary (like or perhaps instead of an info pop-up), or a list of narrative elements with basic information and for navigation, and perhaps simple editing (move, delete cells). Could be useful for long narratives.

markdown:
# Narrative Sprint - To CI (and Beyond!)

This Narrative document is being used to track my progress with this sprint, and to collect thoughts about improvements and enhancements...

# Notes

Blah... bleeh

# Must Fixes

- ~~Toolbar is not always in selected state when cell select - nail down the cases and fix.~~
  - _okay, one use case is when a cell is deleted, and the previous cell is selected._
  - _Fixed: traced the deletion call from kbase's kbaseNarrativeWorkspace, to notebook.js, which takes care of selecting the appropriate cell through cell.select. So extended that method in custom.js so that we can emit an event 'selected.cell' directly to the cell. This event is already set up to do the right thing._ 
  - _It works, and also allowed the removeal of the same event from kbaseNarrative from within the 'select.Cell' handler. It appears that select.Cell is not always called for cell selection within jupyter, instead the direct select method is used, which does not emit an event_
- main buttons disappear after a while after network connection loss (and failed save... but need more testing)
- weird error message upon save of narrative if no network connection (for local dev install, but simulates workspace loss for a narrative?)

## Navbar
- kernel > About Jupyter does nothing.
- login button does not show gravatar
- login button does not show user's name or username
- login dropdown should disappear if user clicks away; right now it only does so if user clicks again

## Login

Login weirdness:

sign out ends up on 404: http://localhost:8888, without login button

can sign in at http://localhost:8888/narrative/tree, which has the sign in button

after login on the tree page, it is not refreshed

if sign out with data filled in, get "Are you sure you want to leave this page? Unsaved changes will be lost" Even if one selects "Saty on page", the logout event proceeds and the narrative "looks" as before, but ...
- it should not be even visible if the user is logged out (close window, redirect, refresh, anything)
- not just narrative, but menu buttons stay there and initiall "work", but will not actually do what you want them to. E.g. share just hangs; kernel menu still works even without auth

if try to save "Narrative savew failed!" with no message, and just OK button; also hyellow message in narrative shows "You do not have permission to view the narrative with id XXX".

login works, and back to normal.

possible to have jupyter keyboard commands leak through in this case - fresh narrative view, make changes, logout out, click stay on page, try to log back in again -- now keystrokes go to ipython and start doing dark magic to one's narrative, and do not appear in the log in form.



## Markdown
- ~~Markdown cell state gets messed up (input AND output) upon going into edit mode.~~
- ~~double clicking should open up and put into edit mode. right now just puts into edit mode without opening, weird...~~
  - _so now it toggles open if it was closed to start with, does nothing additional with edit mode._
  - _next is to hide the output when going into edit mode. my guess is that the toggling gets reversed with the open/close, and the logic for the editor is to simply toggle the output area -- there is not input/output state stored in cell?_
  - _okay, that is now fixed. It was due to the jquery hide()/show() -- show ends up leaving display="block" on the element, even if it was not set originally. The new method adds display="none" and then removes the display style for showing. Also key to this is the method used by the markdown editor to swap the editor and rendered -- it uses a class on the cell (rendered/unrendered) to control the visilibity of the editor/rendered_
  
- exiting from edit mode is annoying. 
  - When blurring on the markdown edit field, it just closes. This makes sense when clicking to another narrative element (perhaps), but not when just blurring out to another app. If one is writing, and needs to activate other windows, etc. as part of that process, it is plain annoying to have the editor close down, lose cursor position, etc.
  
## Code Cells

- when opening a code cell, the widget area prompt is displayed. This is surely another case of the toggle method employed either being too crude or simply out of sync with the way that the notebook hides/shows code cell elements

## Concurrent Usage

There needs to be a better story for concurrent usage of a narrative. As it is, concurrent saves are allowed, and they do not "overwrite" but just will interleave changes in the versions; it does "appear" that there has been overwriting...
So, perhaps better detection of

# Nice to Have

- nicer save / savepoint feedback
- silly hover paragraph icon for markdown cells -- built into notebook, but why? 
- double click expands closed cells,
- remove extraneous items from kernel menu
- "About this Narrative" button/menu item and pop up dialog (or maybe even a cell?) populated with useful info about the narrative - created, last saved, versions, copies...
- narrative preferences: autosave, mode (basic/advanced), 
- run button in cell toolbar for code, app, method cells.
- help! we need more integrated help. For starters:
  - cell specific help - markdown, code cells
  - data cells should at least have (some of the) tools available in the data panel
  - app and method cells could open up a modal narrative method store
- better messaging experience -
   - consistent location for messages
   - better language
   - longer persistence, or long persistence with ability to close
   - message log (at least for the narrative session) with ability to clear, or expand to get more info or help.
   - this could be on the expanded left nav area
- "reset" or "normalize" for app/method cells. The jupyter markdown styling can interfere with widget styling, which causes otherwise good people to put in place hacks to override. (kb output cell something or other). Rather, the style reset should be at the top level, and any specific styling (for input, output, etc) within an app/method cell should be provided by the widget developer (or perhaps even there the app/method cell should provide this...)

# Cool!

- drag and drop cells
- drag and drop apps and methods
- binding of cells to each other (move, d&d, delete, etc.)
- drag and drop code cell and markdown cell 
- basic and advanced mode. Advanced mode would unlock features like code cell icon, kernel menu, and perhaps other ipython stuff
- more metrics: narrative opens, narrative runs, ...

# Ideas / Maybe

Move Apps and Methods into own panel, remove Narratives, make a better dashboard, or a slide out panel for narratives. Narratives is not really a useul tool to have within a narrative, compared to the primary tools of the object browser, app & method browser, and jobs. Also, the narrative browser should have more space -- titles often wrap, there should be search.

Move New Narrative to the horizontal menu (does not exist yet) or simply make a navbar button (for copy too)

Remove the annoying circle buttons at the bottom of the narrative. It is weird to have that be the way to add code and markdown cells, yet data viewers and apps/methods are added from the left side.

Remove the big + circle button from data. It is confusing, since there is already a way to pull up the data panel, and gets in the way.

While on the subject of the left area, perhaps there is a better way to provide "tabs". The horizontal space is very limited, and it may that there are more than major functions to expose. 

For example, what about a narrative summary (like or perhaps instead of an info pop-up), or a list of narrative elements with basic information and for navigation, and perhaps simple editing (move, delete cells). Could be useful for long narratives.

import doekbase.data_api
from doekbase.data_api.taxonomy.taxon.api import TaxonClientAPI
from doekbase.data_api.annotation.genome_annotation.api import GenomeAnnotationClientAPI
from doekbase.data_api.sequence.assembly.api import AssemblyClientAPI

services = {
    "taxon_api_url": "https://ci.kbase.us/services/data/taxon/",
    "assembly_api_url": "https://ci.kbase.us/services/data/assembly/",
    "genome_annotation_api_url": "https://ci.kbase.us/services/data/genome_annotation/"
}

import pandas as pd
import datetime

import bokeh.io
bokeh.io.output_notebook(hide_banner=True)

import os
token = os.environ["KB_AUTH_TOKEN"]

%%javascript
IPython.OutputArea.auto_scroll_threshold = 9999;

def get_genome_summary(genome_annotation=None):
    if genome_annotation is None:
        raise TypeError("No GenomeAnnotation object given.")
        
    #taxon_ref = genome_annotation.get_taxon()
    assembly_ref = genome_annotation.get_assembly()
    assembly = AssemblyClientAPI(services["assembly_api_url"], token, assembly_ref)
    
    overview = dict()
    
    #get assembly info
    assembly_details = dict()
    assembly_details["number_of_contigs"] = assembly.get_number_contigs()
    assembly_details["contig_length"] = assembly.get_contig_lengths()
    assembly_details["contig_gc_content"] = assembly.get_contig_gc_content()
    
    overview["assembly"] = assembly_details
    
    #get annotation info
    annotation_details = dict()
    annotation_details["feature_types"] = genome_annotation.get_feature_types()
    annotation_details["feature_type_descriptions"] = genome_annotation.get_feature_type_descriptions(annotation_details["feature_types"])
    annotation_details["feature_type_counts"] = genome_annotation.get_feature_type_counts(annotation_details["feature_types"])
    
    overview["annotation"] = annotation_details
    
    return overview

def plot_genome_quality(contig_gc_values=None, contig_len_values=None, feature_counts=None, contig_ids=None): from bokeh.plotting import figure, show, gridplot from bokeh.io import hplot, vplot import numpy as np log10_feature_counts = np.log10(feature_counts) log10_contig_len_values = np.log10(contig_len_values) log10_contig_gc_values = np.log10(contig_gc_values) global_scale = 130.0 ### xscale1 = len(contig_gc_values) radius_scale1 = xscale1/global_scale p1 = figure(title="Contig %GC by contig index",background_fill="#FFF5E0",plot_width=400, plot_height=400,title_text_font_size='14pt') p1.scatter(np.arange(0,len(contig_gc_values)), contig_gc_values, marker="circle",radius=log10_feature_counts*radius_scale1, line_color="#6666ee", fill_color="#ee6666", fill_alpha=0.3, size=7, legend="Number of genes") p1.xaxis.axis_label="Contig index" p1.yaxis.axis_label="%GC" global_scale1 = xscale1/radius_scale1 #115.5 (old) ### from scipy.interpolate import spline p2 = def run_genome_quality(genome="kb|g.3157"):
    annotation = GenomeAnnotationClientAPI(services["genome_annotation_api_url"], 
                                           token, 
                                           "ReferenceGenomeAnnotations/{}".format(genome))

    data = dict()
    
    start_fetch = datetime.datetime.utcnow()    
    overview = get_genome_summary(annotation)
    end_fetch = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    
    print "Total time to gather data : {0}".format(end_fetch - start_fetch)
    
    start_prep = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    contig_ids = sorted(overview["assembly"]["contig_length"].keys(), 
                        cmp=lambda x,y: cmp(x.rsplit(".",1)[1],y.rsplit(".",1)[1]))

    contig_len_values = [overview["assembly"]["contig_length"][c] for c in contig_ids]
    contig_gc_values = [100.0 * overview["assembly"]["contig_gc_content"][c] for c in contig_ids]

    count = 0
    start = 0
    length = 1E10

    regions = [{"contig_id": c, "start": start, "length": length, "strand": "?"} for c in contig_ids]
            
    feat_data = annotation.get_feature_ids(group_by="region")
    
    feature_counts = null
    for c in contig_ids:
        count = 0
        for strand in feat_data["by_region"][c]:
            for range in feat_data["by_region"][c][strand]:
                count += len(feat_data["by_region"][c][strand])
        
        if count == 0:
            feature_counts.append(0.1)
        else:
            feature_counts.append(count)
    
    end_prep = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    print "Total time to prep data before plotting : {0}".format(end_prep - start_prep)

    start_plot = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    plot_genome_quality(contig_gc_values, contig_len_values, feature_counts, contig_ids)
    end_plot = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    print "Total time to munge and plot data : {0}".format(end_plot - start_plot)

import doekbase.data_api
from doekbase.data_api.taxonomy.taxon.api import TaxonClientAPI
from doekbase.data_api.annotation.genome_annotation.api import GenomeAnnotationClientAPI
from doekbase.data_api.sequence.assembly.api import AssemblyClientAPI

services = {
    "taxon_api_url": "https://ci.kbase.us/services/data/taxon/",
    "assembly_api_url": "https://ci.kbase.us/services/data/assembly/",
    "genome_annotation_api_url": "https://ci.kbase.us/services/data/genome_annotation/"
}

import pandas as pd
import datetime

import bokeh.io
bokeh.io.output_notebook(hide_banner=True)

import os
token = os.environ["KB_AUTH_TOKEN"]

%%javascript
IPython.OutputArea.auto_scroll_threshold = 9999;

def get_genome_summary(genome_annotation=None):
    if genome_annotation is None:
        raise TypeError("No GenomeAnnotation object given.")
        
    #taxon_ref = genome_annotation.get_taxon()
    assembly_ref = genome_annotation.get_assembly()
    assembly = AssemblyClientAPI(services["assembly_api_url"], token, assembly_ref)
    
    overview = dict()
    
    #get assembly info
    assembly_details = dict()
    assembly_details["number_of_contigs"] = assembly.get_number_contigs()
    assembly_details["contig_length"] = assembly.get_contig_lengths()
    assembly_details["contig_gc_content"] = assembly.get_contig_gc_content()
    
    overview["assembly"] = assembly_details
    
    #get annotation info
    annotation_details = dict()
    annotation_details["feature_types"] = genome_annotation.get_feature_types()
    annotation_details["feature_type_descriptions"] = genome_annotation.get_feature_type_descriptions(annotation_details["feature_types"])
    annotation_details["feature_type_counts"] = genome_annotation.get_feature_type_counts(annotation_details["feature_types"])
    
    overview["annotation"] = annotation_details
    
    return overview

markdown:
A simple narrative demonstrating the KBase data API.
===

This narrative shows how to:
---
- import dependent packages and initialize a KBase gnome annotation data API
- retrieve data for an example genome
- output the results in a narrative table
code:
import doekbase.data_api
from doekbase.data_api.annotation.genome_annotation.api import GenomeAnnotationAPI
from doekbase.data_api.sequence.assembly.api import AssemblyAPI
from doekbase.data_api.taxonomy.taxon.api import TaxonAPI

import pandas as pd

genome="kb|g.3157"

###define ws and shock urls
services = {
        "workspace_service_url": "https://ci.kbase.us/services/ws/",
        "shock_service_url": "https://ci.kbase.us/services/shock-api/",
    }
token = None
s = ""
###initialize GenomeAnnotation API
genome_annotation = GenomeAnnotationAPI(services, token, s.join(("ReferenceGenomeAnnotations/",genome)))

###retrieve the name of this genome annotation
gname=genome_annotation.get_name()
print "genome name : "+gname

###return the feature types available for this genome annotation
feature_types = genome_annotation.get_feature_types()
print "feature_types : " + "".join(feature_types)

###intialize feature count dict
genome_annotation_comparison_dict = dict()

###create dict of table row headers
comparison_keys_dict = dict()
count = 1
for f in feature_types :
    comparison_keys_dict = {f : count}
    count = count +1
    
genome_annotation_comparison_dict[gname] = dict()

###loop over feature types and store feature counts
for i in range(0, len(feature_types)) :
    ###get list of feature ids of this type
    feature_ids = genome_annotation.get_feature_ids(filters={"type_list": [feature_types[i]]})
    feature_add = len(feature_ids["by_type"][feature_types[i]])
    genome_annotation_comparison_dict[gname][feature_types[i]] = feature_add

###create data frame and use default narrative rendering
table = pd.DataFrame(genome_annotation_comparison_dict,columns=genome_annotation_comparison_dict.keys(),index=sorted(comparison_keys_dict, key=comparison_keys_dict.get)) 
table

code:
import doekbase.data_api
from doekbase.data_api.taxonomy.taxon.api import TaxonClientAPI
from doekbase.data_api.annotation.genome_annotation.api import GenomeAnnotationClientAPI
from doekbase.data_api.sequence.assembly.api import AssemblyClientAPI

services = {
    "taxon_api_url": "https://ci.kbase.us/services/data/taxon/",
    "assembly_api_url": "https://ci.kbase.us/services/data/assembly/",
    "genome_annotation_api_url": "https://ci.kbase.us/services/data/genome_annotation/"
}

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import datetime

from scipy.interpolate import spline

from bokeh.plotting import figure, show, gridplot
from bokeh.io import hplot, vplot
bokeh.io.output_notebook(hide_banner=True)

import os
token = os.environ["KB_AUTH_TOKEN"]

#import jinja2
#import IPython.display

%%javascript
IPython.OutputArea.auto_scroll_threshold = 9999;

def get_genome_summary(genome_annotation=None):
    if genome_annotation is None:
        raise TypeError("No GenomeAnnotation object given.")
        
    #taxon_ref = genome_annotation.get_taxon()
    start_time = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    assembly_ref = genome_annotation.get_assembly()
    assembly = AssemblyClientAPI(services["assembly_api_url"], token, assembly_ref)
    end_time = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    print "genome_annotation.get_assembly"
    print "time : {0}".format(end_time - start_time) 
    
    overview = dict()
    
    #get assembly info
    assembly_details = dict()
    start_time = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    assembly_details["number_of_contigs"] = assembly.get_number_contigs()
    end_time = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    print "genome_annotation.get_number_contigs"
    print "time : {0}".format(end_time - start_time) 
    
    start_time = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    assembly_details["contig_length"] = assembly.get_contig_lengths()
    end_time = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    print "genome_annotation.get_contig_lengths"
    print "time : {0}".format(end_time - start_time) 
        
    start_time = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    assembly_details["contig_gc_content"] = assembly.get_contig_gc_content()
    end_time = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    print "genome_annotation.get_contig_gc_content"
    print "time : {0}".format(end_time - start_time) 
        
    overview["assembly"] = assembly_details
    
    #get annotation info
    annotation_details = dict()
    start_time = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    annotation_details["feature_types"] = genome_annotation.get_feature_types()
    end_time = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    print "genome_annotation.get_feature_types"
    print "time : {0}".format(end_time - start_time) 
    
    start_time = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    annotation_details["feature_type_descriptions"] = genome_annotation.get_feature_type_descriptions(annotation_details["feature_types"])
    end_time = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    print "genome_annotation.get_feature_type_descriptions"
    print "time : {0}".format(end_time - start_time) 
    
    start_time = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    annotation_details["feature_type_counts"] = genome_annotation.get_feature_type_counts(annotation_details["feature_types"])
    end_time = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    print "genome_annotation.get_feature_type_counts"
    print "time : {0}".format(end_time - start_time) 
    
    
    overview["annotation"] = annotation_details
    
    return overview

def contig_gc_by_contig(global_scale=None, contig_gc_values=None,log10_feature_counts=None):
    xscale1 = len(contig_gc_values)
    radius_scale1 = xscale1/global_scale
    p1 = figure(title="Contig %GC by contig index",background_fill="#FFF5E0",plot_width=400, plot_height=400,title_text_font_size='14pt')

    #print "contig_gc_values "+str(len(contig_gc_values))
    p1.scatter(np.arange(1,len(contig_gc_values)), contig_gc_values, marker="circle", radius=log10_feature_counts*radius_scale1,line_color="#6666ee", fill_color="#ee6666", fill_alpha=0.3, size=7, legend="Number of genes")
    p1.xaxis.axis_label="Contig index"
    p1.yaxis.axis_label="%GC"
    global_scale1 = xscale1/radius_scale1
    ret = null 
    ret.append(p1)
    ret.append(global_scale1)
    return ret
                                  
def cumul_gc(contig_gc_values=None):
    p2 = figure(title="Cumulative %GC distribution",background_fill="#FFF5E0",plot_width=400, plot_height=400,title_text_font_size='14pt')
    x = np.cumsum(np.sort(contig_gc_values))/np.sum(contig_gc_values)
    y = np.sort(contig_gc_values)

    x_smooth = np.linspace(x.min(), x.max(), 50)
    y_smooth = spline(x, y, x_smooth)
    rev_y_smooth = y_smooth[::-1]

    index = -1
    mindist = 1000000
    for i in np.arange(1,len(y_smooth)):
        dist = abs(rev_y_smooth[i] - y_smooth[i])
        if(dist < mindist):        
            mindist = dist
            index = i

    ynew = np.zeros(shape=(len(y_smooth)))
    for i in np.arange(0,index+1):
        ynew[i] = rev_y_smooth[i] - 2*abs(rev_y_smooth[i] - y_smooth[index])

    for i in np.arange(1,index+2):
        ynew[i+index] = rev_y_smooth[i+index] + 2*abs(rev_y_smooth[i+index] - y_smooth[index])   

    p2.line(x_smooth,y_smooth, color="gray",line_alpha=0.5, line_width=6, legend="Contig %GC distribution")
    p2.line(x_smooth,ynew, color="red",line_alpha=0.5,line_width=6, legend="Contig %GC distribution assymetry")

    p2.circle(x, y,
                line_color="black", fill_color="gray", fill_alpha=1, size=2, legend="Contig %GC values")

    p2.xaxis.axis_label="Fraction contigs < %GC"
    p2.yaxis.axis_label="%GC"
    p2.legend.orientation = "top_left"
    p2.xaxis.bounds = (0,1)
    return p2
                                  
def contig_gc_by_contiglen(global_scale=None, contig_len_values=None,contig_gc_values=None,log10_feature_counts=None):
    xscale3 = max(contig_len_values) - min(contig_len_values)
    radius_scale3 = xscale3/global_scale
    p3 = figure(title="Contig %GC by contig length",background_fill="#FFF5E0",plot_width=400, plot_height=400,title_text_font_size='14pt')
    p3.scatter(contig_len_values, contig_gc_values, marker="circle",radius=log10_feature_counts*radius_scale3,
                line_color="#6666ee", fill_color="#ee6666", fill_alpha=0.3, size=7, legend="Number of genes")
    p3.xaxis.axis_label="Contig length (bp)"
    p3.yaxis.axis_label="%GC"
    
    global_scale3 = xscale3/radius_scale3
    return [p3, global_scale3]
    
                                  
def contig_gc_by_logcontiglen(global_scale=None, contig_gc_values=None,log10_contig_len_values=None,log10_feature_counts=None):
    xscale4 = max(log10_contig_len_values) - min(log10_contig_len_values)    
    radius_scale4 = xscale4/global_scale
    p4 = figure(title="Contig %GC by log10 contig length",background_fill="#FFF5E0",plot_width=400, plot_height=400,title_text_font_size='14pt') 
    p4.scatter(log10_contig_len_values, contig_gc_values, marker="circle", radius=log10_feature_counts*radius_scale4,
                line_color="#6666ee", fill_color="#ee6666", fill_alpha=0.3, size=7, legend="Number of genes")
    p4.xaxis.axis_label="Log10 Contig length (bp)"
    p4.yaxis.axis_label="%GC"

    global_scale4 = xscale4/radius_scale4
    return [p4, global_scale4]

def featurecount_by_contiglen(global_scale=None, contig_len_values=None,log10_feature_counts=None,log10_contig_gc_values=None):
    xscale9 = max(contig_len_values) - min(contig_len_values)
    radius_scale9 = xscale9/global_scale
    p9 = figure(title="Feature count by contig length",background_fill="#FFF5E0",plot_width=400, plot_height=400,title_text_font_size='14pt')
    p9.scatter(contig_len_values, log10_feature_counts, marker="circle",radius=np.asarray(log10_contig_gc_values)*radius_scale9,
                line_color="#6666ee", fill_color="#ee6666", fill_alpha=0.3, size=7, legend="%GC")
    p9.xaxis.axis_label="Contig length (bp)"
    p9.yaxis.axis_label="Log10 Number of genes"
    p9.legend.orientation = "bottom_right"
    
    global_scale9 = xscale9/radius_scale9
    return [p9, global_scale9]
                                  
def featurecount_by_logcontiglen(global_scale=None, log10_contig_len_values=None,log10_contig_gc_values=None,log10_feature_counts=None):
    xscale10 = max(log10_contig_len_values) - min(log10_contig_len_values)    
    radius_scale10 = xscale10/global_scale
    p10 = figure(title="Feature count by log10 contig length",background_fill="#FFF5E0",plot_width=400, plot_height=400,title_text_font_size='14pt') 
    p10.scatter(log10_contig_len_values, log10_feature_counts, marker="circle", radius=np.asarray(log10_contig_gc_values)*radius_scale10,
                line_color="#6666ee", fill_color="#ee6666", fill_alpha=0.3, size=7, legend="%GC")
    p10.xaxis.axis_label="Log10 Contig length (bp)"
    p10.yaxis.axis_label="Log10 Number of genes"
    p10.legend.orientation = "bottom_right"
    
    global_scale10 = xscale10/radius_scale10
    return [p10, global_scale10]
                                  
def contig_gc_stats(contig_gc_values=None):
    mu5 = np.mean(contig_gc_values)
    mu5print = "{:3.1f}".format(mu5)
    sigma5 = np.std(contig_gc_values)
    sigma5print = "{:3.1f}".format(sigma5)
    skew5 = scipy.stats.skew(contig_gc_values)
    skew5print = "{:3.1f}".format(skew5)
    #print(skew5print)  
    
    p5 = figure(title="Contig %GC (μ={mu5print}, σ={sigma5print}, sk={skew5print})".format(**vars()),tools="save",
       background_fill="#FFF5E0",plot_width=400, plot_height=400,title_text_font_size='14pt')

    #measured = np.random.normal(mu, sigma, 1000)
    hist5, edges5 = np.histogram(contig_gc_values, density=True, bins=50)

    x = np.linspace(min(contig_gc_values), max(contig_gc_values), 100)
    pdf = 1/(sigma5 * np.sqrt(2*np.pi)) * np.exp(-(x-mu5)**2 / (2*sigma5**2))
    cdf = (1+scipy.special.erf((x-mu5)/np.sqrt(2*sigma5**2)))/2

    p5.quad(top=hist5, bottom=0, left=edges5[:-1], right=edges5[1:],
         fill_color="#59D659", line_color="#59D659")
    p5.line(x, pdf, line_color="#D17519", line_width=4, alpha=0.7, legend="Normal PDF estimate")
    p5.line(x, cdf, line_color="#4D504D", line_width=2, alpha=0.7, legend="CDF")

    p5.legend.orientation = "top_left"
    p5.xaxis.axis_label = 'Contig %GC'
    p5.yaxis.axis_label = 'Pr(Contig %GC)'
    return p5
                                  
def contig_len_stats(contig_len_values=None):
    contig_lengths_log10 = np.log10(contig_len_values)
    mu6 = np.mean(contig_lengths_log10)
    mu6print = "{:2.0f}".format(mu6)
    sigma6 = np.std(contig_lengths_log10)
    sigma6print = "{:2.0f}".format(sigma6)
    skew6 = scipy.stats.skew(contig_lengths_log10)
    skew6print = "{:3.1f}".format(skew6)
    
    p6 = figure(title="Log10 Contig lengths (μ={mu6print}, σ={sigma6print}, sk={skew6print})".format(**vars()),tools="save",
       background_fill="#FFF5E0",plot_width=400, plot_height=400,title_text_font_size='14pt')

    #measured = np.random.normal(mu, sigma, 1000)
    hist6, edges6 = np.histogram(contig_lengths_log10, density=True, bins=50)
    #print hist6
    #print contig_lengths_log10
    
    x = np.linspace(min(contig_lengths_log10), max(contig_lengths_log10), 100)
    pdf = 1/(sigma6 * np.sqrt(2*np.pi)) * np.exp(-(x-mu6)**2 / (2*sigma6**2))
    cdf = (1+scipy.special.erf((x-mu6)/np.sqrt(2*sigma6**2)))/2

    p6.quad(top=hist6, bottom=0, left=edges6[:-1], right=edges6[1:],
         fill_color="#59D659", line_color="#59D659")
    p6.line(x, pdf, line_color="#D17519", line_width=4, alpha=0.7, legend="Normal PDF estimate")
    p6.line(x, cdf, line_color="#4D504D", line_width=2, alpha=0.7, legend="CDF")

    p6.legend.orientation = "top_left"
    p6.xaxis.axis_label = 'Log10 Contig lengths (bp)'
    p6.yaxis.axis_label = 'Pr(Length)'
    return p6

def genes_stats(log10_feature_counts=None):
    mu7 = np.mean(log10_feature_counts)
    mu7print = "{:2.0f}".format(mu7)
    sigma7 = np.std(log10_feature_counts)
    sigma7print = "{:2.0f}".format(sigma7)
    skew7 = scipy.stats.skew(log10_feature_counts)
    skew7print = "{:3.1f}".format(skew7)
    
    p7 = figure(title="Log10 number of genes (μ={mu7print}, σ={sigma7print}, sk={skew7print})".format(**vars()),tools="save",
       background_fill="#FFF5E0",plot_width=400, plot_height=400,title_text_font_size='14pt')

    #measured = np.random.normal(mu, sigma, 1000)
    hist7, edges7 = np.histogram(log10_feature_counts, density=True, bins=50)
    #print hist6
    #print contig_lengths_log10
    
    x = np.linspace(min(log10_feature_counts), max(log10_feature_counts), 100)
    pdf = 1/(sigma7 * np.sqrt(2*np.pi)) * np.exp(-(x-mu7)**2 / (2*sigma7**2))
    cdf = (1+scipy.special.erf((x-mu7)/np.sqrt(2*sigma7**2)))/2

    p7.quad(top=hist7, bottom=0, left=edges7[:-1], right=edges7[1:],
         fill_color="#59D659", line_color="#59D659")
    p7.line(x, pdf, line_color="#D17519", line_width=4, alpha=0.7, legend="Normal PDF estimate")
    p7.line(x, cdf, line_color="#4D504D", line_width=2, alpha=0.7, legend="CDF")

    p7.legend.orientation = "top_left"
    p7.xaxis.axis_label = 'Log10 number of genes'
    p7.yaxis.axis_label = 'Pr(Length)'
    return p7
                                  
def Nx_plot(contig_len_values=None,contig_ids=None):
    length_dict = dict()
    count = 0
    
    #print "contig_ids"
    #print contig_ids
    
    for c in contig_ids:
        length_dict[c] = contig_len_values[count]
        count += 1

    ###code to sort along with contig ids
    #sorted_length = sorted(length_dict.items(), key=operator.itemgetter(1))

    sorted_len_ar = np.asarray(sorted(length_dict.values()))[::-1]
    sum = np.sum(sorted_len_ar)
    cumsum = np.cumsum(sorted_len_ar)
    cumsum_norm = 100.0 * cumsum.astype('f') / (sum + 0.0)

    xs = np.zeros(2 * len(cumsum_norm)-2)
    ys = np.zeros(2 * len(cumsum_norm)-2)
    xs[0] = 0
    xs[1] = cumsum_norm[0]
    ys[0] = sorted_len_ar[0]
    ys[1] = sorted_len_ar[0]

    for i in  range(1,len(cumsum_norm)-1,1):
        xs[2*i] = cumsum_norm[i-1]
        xs[2*i+1] = cumsum_norm[i]
        ys[2*i] = sorted_len_ar[i]
        ys[2*i+1] = sorted_len_ar[i]

    maxy =  max(ys)
    p8 = figure(title="Nx plot for contig length",background_fill="#FFF5E0",plot_width=400, plot_height=400,title_text_font_size='14pt')
    p8.line(xs, ys, line_color="#6666ee", line_width=2, alpha=0.7,legend="Nx")
    p8.line([50, 50], [0,maxy], line_color="red", line_width=2, alpha=0.7,legend="N50")
    ###the below line prints NaN, puzzling
    #p8.text(50, maxy, "N50 = ")
    p8.xaxis.axis_label="Nx"
    p8.yaxis.axis_label="Contig length"
    return p8

#Function to create a set of genome quality plots
def plot_genome_quality(contig_gc_values=None,contig_len_values=None,feature_counts=None, contig_ids=None):        

    log10_feature_counts = np.log10(feature_counts)    
    log10_contig_len_values = np.log10(contig_len_values)
    log10_contig_gc_values = np.log10(contig_gc_values)     

    global_scale = 130.0
        
    ### 
    ret1 = contig_gc_by_contig(global_scale, contig_gc_values,log10_feature_counts)
    p1 = ret1[0]
    global_scale1 = ret1[1]                              
             
    ###Cumulative %GC distribution
    p2 = cumul_gc(contig_gc_values)
         
    ###Contig %GC by contig length
    ret3 = contig_gc_by_contiglen(global_scale, contig_len_values,contig_gc_values,log10_feature_counts)
    p3 = ret3[0]
    global_scale3 = ret3[1]                              
       
    ###Contig %GC by log10 contig length
    ret4 = contig_gc_by_logcontiglen(global_scale,contig_gc_values,log10_contig_len_values,log10_feature_counts)
    p4 = ret4[0]
    global_scale4 = ret4[1]   
    
    #def featurecount_by_contiglen(global_scale=None, contig_len_values=None,log10_feature_counts=None,log10_contig_gc_values=None):
    ###Feature count by contig length

def contig_gc_by_contig(global_scale=None, contig_gc_values=None,log10_feature_counts=None):
    xscale1 = len(contig_gc_values)
    radius_scale1 = xscale1/global_scale
    p1 = figure(title="Contig %GC by contig index",background_fill="#FFF5E0",plot_width=400, plot_height=400,title_text_font_size='14pt')

    #print "contig_gc_values "+str(len(contig_gc_values))
    p1.scatter(np.arange(1,len(contig_gc_values)), contig_gc_values, marker="circle", radius=log10_feature_counts*radius_scale1,line_color="#6666ee", fill_color="#ee6666", fill_alpha=0.3, size=7, legend="Number of genes")
    p1.xaxis.axis_label="Contig index"
    p1.yaxis.axis_label="%GC"
    global_scale1 = xscale1/radius_scale1
    ret = null 
    ret.append(p1)
    ret.append(global_scale1)
    return ret
                                  
def cumul_gc(contig_gc_values=None):
    p2 = figure(title="Cumulative %GC distribution",background_fill="#FFF5E0",plot_width=400, plot_height=400,title_text_font_size='14pt')
    x = np.cumsum(np.sort(contig_gc_values))/np.sum(contig_gc_values)
    y = np.sort(contig_gc_values)

    x_smooth = np.linspace(x.min(), x.max(), 50)
    y_smooth = spline(x, y, x_smooth)
    rev_y_smooth = y_smooth[::-1]

    index = -1
    mindist = 1000000
    for i in np.arange(1,len(y_smooth)):
        dist = abs(rev_y_smooth[i] - y_smooth[i])
        if(dist < mindist):        
            mindist = dist
            index = i

    ynew = np.zeros(shape=(len(y_smooth)))
    for i in np.arange(0,index+1):
        ynew[i] = rev_y_smooth[i] - 2*abs(rev_y_smooth[i] - y_smooth[index])

    for i in np.arange(1,index+2):
        ynew[i+index] = rev_y_smooth[i+index] + 2*abs(rev_y_smooth[i+index] - y_smooth[index])   

    p2.line(x_smooth,y_smooth, color="gray",line_alpha=0.5, line_width=6, legend="Contig %GC distribution")
    p2.line(x_smooth,ynew, color="red",line_alpha=0.5,line_width=6, legend="Contig %GC distribution assymetry")

    p2.circle(x, y,
                line_color="black", fill_color="gray", fill_alpha=1, size=2, legend="Contig %GC values")

    p2.xaxis.axis_label="Fraction contigs < %GC"
    p2.yaxis.axis_label="%GC"
    p2.legend.orientation = "top_left"
    p2.xaxis.bounds = (0,1)
    return p2
                                  
def contig_gc_by_contiglen(global_scale=None, contig_len_values=None,contig_gc_values=None,log10_feature_counts=None):
    xscale3 = max(contig_len_values) - min(contig_len_values)
    radius_scale3 = xscale3/global_scale
    p3 = figure(title="Contig %GC by contig length",background_fill="#FFF5E0",plot_width=400, plot_height=400,title_text_font_size='14pt')
    p3.scatter(contig_len_values, contig_gc_values, marker="circle",radius=log10_feature_counts*radius_scale3,
                line_color="#6666ee", fill_color="#ee6666", fill_alpha=0.3, size=7, legend="Number of genes")
    p3.xaxis.axis_label="Contig length (bp)"
    p3.yaxis.axis_label="%GC"
    
    global_scale3 = xscale3/radius_scale3
    return [p3, global_scale3]
    
                                  
def contig_gc_by_logcontiglen(global_scale=None, contig_gc_values=None,log10_contig_len_values=None,log10_feature_counts=None):
    xscale4 = max(log10_contig_len_values) - min(log10_contig_len_values)    
    radius_scale4 = xscale4/global_scale
    p4 = figure(title="Contig %GC by log10 contig length",background_fill="#FFF5E0",plot_width=400, plot_height=400,title_text_font_size='14pt') 
    p4.scatter(log10_contig_len_values, contig_gc_values, marker="circle", radius=log10_feature_counts*radius_scale4,
                line_color="#6666ee", fill_color="#ee6666", fill_alpha=0.3, size=7, legend="Number of genes")
    p4.xaxis.axis_label="Log10 Contig length (bp)"
    p4.yaxis.axis_label="%GC"

    global_scale4 = xscale4/radius_scale4
    return [p4, global_scale4]

def featurecount_by_contiglen(global_scale=None, contig_len_values=None,log10_feature_counts=None,log10_contig_gc_values=None):
    xscale9 = max(contig_len_values) - min(contig_len_values)
    radius_scale9 = xscale9/global_scale
    p9 = figure(title="Feature count by contig length",background_fill="#FFF5E0",plot_width=400, plot_height=400,title_text_font_size='14pt')
    p9.scatter(contig_len_values, log10_feature_counts, marker="circle",radius=np.asarray(log10_contig_gc_values)*radius_scale9,
                line_color="#6666ee", fill_color="#ee6666", fill_alpha=0.3, size=7, legend="%GC")
    p9.xaxis.axis_label="Contig length (bp)"
    p9.yaxis.axis_label="Log10 Number of genes"
    p9.legend.orientation = "bottom_right"
    
    global_scale9 = xscale9/radius_scale9
    return [p9, global_scale9]
                                  
def featurecount_by_logcontiglen(global_scale=None, log10_contig_len_values=None,log10_contig_gc_values=None,log10_feature_counts=None):
    xscale10 = max(log10_contig_len_values) - min(log10_contig_len_values)    
    radius_scale10 = xscale10/global_scale
    p10 = figure(title="Feature count by log10 contig length",background_fill="#FFF5E0",plot_width=400, plot_height=400,title_text_font_size='14pt') 
    p10.scatter(log10_contig_len_values, log10_feature_counts, marker="circle", radius=np.asarray(log10_contig_gc_values)*radius_scale10,
                line_color="#6666ee", fill_color="#ee6666", fill_alpha=0.3, size=7, legend="%GC")
    p10.xaxis.axis_label="Log10 Contig length (bp)"
    p10.yaxis.axis_label="Log10 Number of genes"
    p10.legend.orientation = "bottom_right"
    
    global_scale10 = xscale10/radius_scale10
    return [p10, global_scale10]
                                  
def contig_gc_stats(contig_gc_values=None):
    mu5 = np.mean(contig_gc_values)
    mu5print = "{:3.1f}".format(mu5)
    sigma5 = np.std(contig_gc_values)
    sigma5print = "{:3.1f}".format(sigma5)
    skew5 = scipy.stats.skew(contig_gc_values)
    skew5print = "{:3.1f}".format(skew5)
    #print(skew5print)  
    
    p5 = figure(title="Contig %GC (μ={mu5print}, σ={sigma5print}, sk={skew5print})".format(**vars()),tools="save",
       background_fill="#FFF5E0",plot_width=400, plot_height=400,title_text_font_size='14pt')

    #measured = np.random.normal(mu, sigma, 1000)
    hist5, edges5 = np.histogram(contig_gc_values, density=True, bins=50)

    x = np.linspace(min(contig_gc_values), max(contig_gc_values), 100)
    pdf = 1/(sigma5 * np.sqrt(2*np.pi)) * np.exp(-(x-mu5)**2 / (2*sigma5**2))
    cdf = (1+scipy.special.erf((x-mu5)/np.sqrt(2*sigma5**2)))/2

    p5.quad(top=hist5, bottom=0, left=edges5[:-1], right=edges5[1:],
         fill_color="#59D659", line_color="#59D659")
    p5.line(x, pdf, line_color="#D17519", line_width=4, alpha=0.7, legend="Normal PDF estimate")
    p5.line(x, cdf, line_color="#4D504D", line_width=2, alpha=0.7, legend="CDF")

    p5.legend.orientation = "top_left"
    p5.xaxis.axis_label = 'Contig %GC'
    p5.yaxis.axis_label = 'Pr(Contig %GC)'
    return p5
                                  
def contig_len_stats(contig_len_values=None):
    contig_lengths_log10 = np.log10(contig_len_values)
    mu6 = np.mean(contig_lengths_log10)
    mu6print = "{:2.0f}".format(mu6)
    sigma6 = np.std(contig_lengths_log10)
    sigma6print = "{:2.0f}".format(sigma6)
    skew6 = scipy.stats.skew(contig_lengths_log10)
    skew6print = "{:3.1f}".format(skew6)
    
    p6 = figure(title="Log10 Contig lengths (μ={mu6print}, σ={sigma6print}, sk={skew6print})".format(**vars()),tools="save",
       background_fill="#FFF5E0",plot_width=400, plot_height=400,title_text_font_size='14pt')

    #measured = np.random.normal(mu, sigma, 1000)
    hist6, edges6 = np.histogram(contig_lengths_log10, density=True, bins=50)
    #print hist6
    #print contig_lengths_log10
    
    x = np.linspace(min(contig_lengths_log10), max(contig_lengths_log10), 100)
    pdf = 1/(sigma6 * np.sqrt(2*np.pi)) * np.exp(-(x-mu6)**2 / (2*sigma6**2))
    cdf = (1+scipy.special.erf((x-mu6)/np.sqrt(2*sigma6**2)))/2

    p6.quad(top=hist6, bottom=0, left=edges6[:-1], right=edges6[1:],
         fill_color="#59D659", line_color="#59D659")
    p6.line(x, pdf, line_color="#D17519", line_width=4, alpha=0.7, legend="Normal PDF estimate")
    p6.line(x, cdf, line_color="#4D504D", line_width=2, alpha=0.7, legend="CDF")

    p6.legend.orientation = "top_left"
    p6.xaxis.axis_label = 'Log10 Contig lengths (bp)'
    p6.yaxis.axis_label = 'Pr(Length)'
    return p6

def genes_stats(log10_feature_counts=None):
    mu7 = np.mean(log10_feature_counts)
    mu7print = "{:2.0f}".format(mu7)
    sigma7 = np.std(log10_feature_counts)
    sigma7print = "{:2.0f}".format(sigma7)
    skew7 = scipy.stats.skew(log10_feature_counts)
    skew7print = "{:3.1f}".format(skew7)
    
    p7 = figure(title="Log10 number of genes (μ={mu7print}, σ={sigma7print}, sk={skew7print})".format(**vars()),tools="save",
       background_fill="#FFF5E0",plot_width=400, plot_height=400,title_text_font_size='14pt')

    #measured = np.random.normal(mu, sigma, 1000)
    hist7, edges7 = np.histogram(log10_feature_counts, density=True, bins=50)
    #print hist6
    #print contig_lengths_log10
    
    x = np.linspace(min(log10_feature_counts), max(log10_feature_counts), 100)
    pdf = 1/(sigma7 * np.sqrt(2*np.pi)) * np.exp(-(x-mu7)**2 / (2*sigma7**2))
    cdf = (1+scipy.special.erf((x-mu7)/np.sqrt(2*sigma7**2)))/2

    p7.quad(top=hist7, bottom=0, left=edges7[:-1], right=edges7[1:],
         fill_color="#59D659", line_color="#59D659")
    p7.line(x, pdf, line_color="#D17519", line_width=4, alpha=0.7, legend="Normal PDF estimate")
    p7.line(x, cdf, line_color="#4D504D", line_width=2, alpha=0.7, legend="CDF")

    p7.legend.orientation = "top_left"
    p7.xaxis.axis_label = 'Log10 number of genes'
    p7.yaxis.axis_label = 'Pr(Length)'
    return p7
                                  
def Nx_plot(contig_len_values=None,contig_ids=None):
    length_dict = dict()
    count = 0
    
    #print "contig_ids"
    #print contig_ids
    
    for c in contig_ids:
        length_dict[c] = contig_len_values[count]
        count += 1

    ###code to sort along with contig ids
    #sorted_length = sorted(length_dict.items(), key=operator.itemgetter(1))

    sorted_len_ar = np.asarray(sorted(length_dict.values()))[::-1]
    sum = np.sum(sorted_len_ar)
    cumsum = np.cumsum(sorted_len_ar)
    cumsum_norm = 100.0 * cumsum.astype('f') / (sum + 0.0)

    xs = np.zeros(2 * len(cumsum_norm)-2)
    ys = np.zeros(2 * len(cumsum_norm)-2)
    xs[0] = 0
    xs[1] = cumsum_norm[0]
    ys[0] = sorted_len_ar[0]
    ys[1] = sorted_len_ar[0]

    for i in  range(1,len(cumsum_norm)-1,1):
        xs[2*i] = cumsum_norm[i-1]
        xs[2*i+1] = cumsum_norm[i]
        ys[2*i] = sorted_len_ar[i]
        ys[2*i+1] = sorted_len_ar[i]

    maxy =  max(ys)
    p8 = figure(title="Nx plot for contig length",background_fill="#FFF5E0",plot_width=400, plot_height=400,title_text_font_size='14pt')
    p8.line(xs, ys, line_color="#6666ee", line_width=2, alpha=0.7,legend="Nx")
    p8.line([50, 50], [0,maxy], line_color="red", line_width=2, alpha=0.7,legend="N50")
    ###the below line prints NaN, puzzling
    #p8.text(50, maxy, "N50 = ")
    p8.xaxis.axis_label="Nx"
    p8.yaxis.axis_label="Contig length"
    return p8

#Function to create a set of genome quality plots
def plot_genome_quality(contig_gc_values=None,contig_len_values=None,feature_counts=None, contig_ids=None):        

    log10_feature_counts = np.log10(feature_counts)    
    log10_contig_len_values = np.log10(contig_len_values)
    log10_contig_gc_values = np.log10(contig_gc_values)     

    global_scale = 130.0
        
    ### 
    ret1 = contig_gc_by_contig(global_scale, contig_gc_values,log10_feature_counts)
    p1 = ret1[0]
    global_scale1 = ret1[1]                              
             
    ###Cumulative %GC distribution
    p2 = cumul_gc(contig_gc_values)
         
    ###Contig %GC by contig length
    ret3 = contig_gc_by_contiglen(global_scale, contig_len_values,contig_gc_values,log10_feature_counts)
    p3 = ret3[0]
    global_scale3 = ret3[1]                              
       
    ###Contig %GC by log10 contig length
    ret4 = contig_gc_by_logcontiglen(global_scale,contig_gc_values,log10_contig_len_values,log10_feature_counts)
    p4 = ret4[0]
    global_scale4 = ret4[1]   
    
    #def featurecount_by_contiglen(global_scale=None, contig_len_values=None,log10_feature_counts=None,log10_contig_gc_values=None):
    ###Feature count by contig length
    ret9 = featurecount_by_contiglen(global_scale, contig_len_values,log10_feature_counts,log10_contig_gc_values)
    p9 = ret9[0]
    global_scale9 = ret9[1]   
    
    #def featurecount_by_logcontiglen(global_scale=None, contig_gc_values=None,log10_feature_counts=None):
    ###Feature count by log10 contig length
    ret10 = featurecount_by_logcontiglen(global_scale, log10_contig_len_values,log10_contig_gc_values,log10_feature_counts)#,log10_contig_gc_values)
    p10 = ret10[0]
    global_scale10 = ret10[1]   
    
    #print xscale1, xscale3, xscale4, xscale9, xscale10
    #print global_scale1,global_scale3, global_scale4, global_scale9, global_scale10
       
    ###Contig %GC (μ={mu5print}, σ={sigma5print}, sk={skew5print})
    p5 = contig_gc_stats(contig_gc_values) 
       
    ###Log10 Contig lengths (μ={mu6print}, σ={sigma6print}, sk={skew6print})
    p6 = contig_len_stats(contig_len_values)
    
    ###Log10 number of genes (μ={mu6print}, σ={sigma6print}, sk={skew6print})
    p7 = genes_stats(log10_feature_counts)
    
    ###Nx plot for contig length
    p8 = Nx_plot(contig_len_values,contig_ids)

    #arrange all panels into single plot
    masterp = gridplot([[p1, p2], [p3, p4], [p9, p10], [p5, p7],[p6, p8]])

    show(masterp)

def run_genome_quality(genome="kb|g.166819"):#4435/337/1#ReferenceGenomeAnnotations/kb|g.3157
    annotation = GenomeAnnotationClientAPI(services["genome_annotation_api_url"], 
                                           token, "ReferenceGenomeAnnotations/{}".format(genome))#
    
    print annotation.get_feature_types()
    
    data = dict()
    
    start_fetch = datetime.datetime.utcnow()    
    overview = get_genome_summary(annotation)
    end_fetch = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    
    print "Total time to gather data : {0}".format(end_fetch - start_fetch)
    
    start_prep = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    contig_ids = sorted(overview["assembly"]["contig_length"].keys(), 
                        cmp=lambda x,y: cmp(x.rsplit(".",1)[1],y.rsplit(".",1)[1]))

    contig_len_values = [overview["assembly"]["contig_length"][c] for c in contig_ids]
    contig_gc_values = [100.0 * overview["assembly"]["contig_gc_content"][c] for c in contig_ids]

    count = 0
    start = 0
    length = 1E10

    regions = [{"contig_id": c, "start": start, "length": length, "strand": "?"} for c in contig_ids]
            
    feat_data = annotation.get_feature_ids(group_by="region")
    
    feature_counts = null
    for c in contig_ids:
        count = 0
        for strand in feat_data["by_region"][c]:
            for range in feat_data["by_region"][c][strand]:
                count += len(feat_data["by_region"][c][strand])
        
        if count == 0:
            feature_counts.append(0.1)
        else:
            feature_counts.append(count)
    
    end_prep = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    print "Total time to prep data before plotting : {0}".format(end_prep - start_prep)

    start_plot = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    plot_genome_quality(contig_gc_values, contig_len_values, feature_counts, contig_ids)
    end_plot = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    print "Total time to munge and plot data : {0}".format(end_plot - start_plot)
run_genome_quality("kb|g.166819")
run_genome_quality("kb|g.140106")

markdown:
A simple narrative demonstrating the KBase data API.
===

This narrative shows how to:
---
- import dependent packages and initialize a KBase gnome annotation data API
- retrieve data for an example genome
- output the results in a narrative table
code:
import os
import datetime

token = os.environ["KB_AUTH_TOKEN"]

# these are for client-server communication
from doekbase.data_api.annotation.genome_annotation.api import GenomeAnnotationClientAPI
from doekbase.data_api.taxonomy.taxon.api import TaxonClientAPI
from doekbase.data_api.sequence.assembly.api import AssemblyClientAPI
# the ObjectClientAPI is not ready yet, coming soon

import pandas as pd

taxonurl='https://ci.kbase.us/services/data/taxon'
assemblyurl='https://ci.kbase.us/services/data/assembly'
genomeannotationurl='https://ci.kbase.us/services/data/annotation'

ref='ReferenceGenomeAnnotations/kb|g.3899'

# genome annotation object
annoapi = GenomeAnnotationClientAPI(genomeannotationurl, token, ref)
print annoapi

#gname=annoapi.get_name()

print "get_feature_types"
start_time = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
feature_types = annoapi.get_feature_types()
end_time = datetime.datetime.utcnow()    
print "Time : {0}".format(end_time - start_time)   
print "feature_types : " + '[%s]' % ', '.join(map(str, feature_types))

###intialize feature count dict
genome_annotation_comparison_dict = dict()

###create dict of table row headers
comparison_keys_dict = dict()
count = 0
for f in feature_types :
    print "feature_types dict "+f + "  " + str(count)
    comparison_keys_dict = {f : count}
    count = count +1
    
genome_annotation_comparison_dict[ref] = dict()

###loop over feature types and store feature counts
for i in range(0, len(feature_types)) :
    ###get list of feature ids of this type    
    print "get_feature_ids "+feature_types[i]
    assembly_details = dict()
    start_time = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    feature_ids = annoapi.get_feature_ids(filters={"type_list": [feature_types[i]]})
    feature_add = len(feature_ids["by_type"][feature_types[i]])
    genome_annotation_comparison_dict[ref][feature_types[i]] = feature_add
    end_time = datetime.datetime.utcnow()    
    print "Time : {0}".format(end_time - start_time)   
    
###create data frame and use default narrative rendering
table = pd.DataFrame(genome_annotation_comparison_dict,columns=genome_annotation_comparison_dict.keys(),index=sorted(comparison_keys_dict, key=comparison_keys_dict.get)) 
table

code:
import doekbase.data_api
from doekbase.data_api.taxonomy.taxon.api import TaxonAPI
from doekbase.data_api.annotation.genome_annotation.api import GenomeAnnotationAPI
from doekbase.data_api.sequence.assembly.api import AssemblyAPI
import pdb
import pandas as pd
import datetime

services = {"workspace_service_url": "https://ci.kbase.us/services/ws/",
            "shock_service_url": "https://ci.kbase.us/services/shock-api/"}

import os
token = os.environ["KB_AUTH_TOKEN"]

from doekbase.data_api.core import ObjectAPI

pd.set_option('display.width', 1000)

alias_detail_display = True


print "start"
start_time = datetime.datetime.utcnow()

arabidopsis_taxon = TaxonAPI(services, token=token, ref="ReferenceTaxons/3702_taxon")

genome_annotations = arabidopsis_taxon.get_genome_annotations()  
max_version_genome_annotations = dict() # key is object reference, value is genome_annotation

#GET THE MAX VERSION OF GENOME ANNOTATION
for genome_annotation in genome_annotations:
    object_reference = genome_annotation.get_info()['object_reference']
    if object_reference not in max_version_genome_annotations:
        max_version_genome_annotations[object_reference] = genome_annotation
    else:
        temp_annotation = max_version_genome_annotations[object_reference]
        if int(genome_annotation.get_version()) > int(temp_annotation.get_version()):
            max_version_genome_annotations[object_reference] = genome_annotation

print ""
print ("Number of total GenomeAnnotations (all versions): %s" % (str(len(genome_annotations))))
genome_annotations = max_version_genome_annotations.values()
print ("Number of total distinct GenomeAnnotation objects (max version of each object): %s" % (str(len(genome_annotations))))
genome_annotation_comparison_dict = dict()
comparison_keys_dict = {"Assembly Size":1,"Number of Contigs":2,"GC Content":3 ,"MD5":4, "Date":5, "Number of Feature Types":12}
distinct_feature_types_dict = dict()

total_distinct_alias_sources_dict = dict()

# Pull out data for each G.A.
for genome_annotation in genome_annotations:
    key = "%s_%s" % (genome_annotation.get_data_subset(["genome_annotation_id"])["genome_annotation_id"],str(genome_annotation.get_info()['object_reference']))
    genome_annotation_comparison_dict[key] = dict()
    assembly = genome_annotation.get_assembly()
    genome_annotation_comparison_dict[key]["Assembly Size"] = str(assembly.get_dna_size())
    genome_annotation_comparison_dict[key]["Number of Contigs"] = str(assembly.get_number_contigs())
    genome_annotation_comparison_dict[key]["GC Content"] = str(round(assembly.get_gc_content(),4))
    genome_annotation_comparison_dict[key]["MD5"] = assembly.get_data_subset(["md5"])["md5"]
    if "external_source_origination_date" in genome_annotation.get_data_subset(["external_source_origination_date"]):
        genome_annotation_comparison_dict[key]["Date"] = genome_annotation.get_data_subset(["external_source_origination_date"])["external_source_origination_date"]
    genome_annotation_comparison_dict[key]["Number of Feature Types"] = str(len(genome_annotation.get_feature_types()))
    feature_counts = genome_annotation.get_feature_type_counts()
    for feature_type in feature_counts:
        feature_key = feature_type + " counts"
        distinct_feature_types_dict[feature_key] = 1
        genome_annotation_comparison_dict[key][feature_key] = feature_counts[feature_type]
    

display_counter = 15
for feature_type in sorted(distinct_feature_types_dict.iterkeys()) :
    comparison_keys_dict[feature_type] = display_counter
    display_counter += 1

end_time = datetime.datetime.utcnow()  
print "Time : {0}".format(end_time - start_time)   


table = pd.DataFrame(genome_annotation_comparison_dict,columns=genome_annotation_comparison_dict.keys(),index=sorted(comparison_keys_dict, key=comparison_keys_dict.get)) 
#print tabulate(table, headers='keys', tablefmt='psql')
table

markdown: KBase Data APIs === The Data API is an access layer for both reference and user data in KBase. * API documentation * GitHub repository README There are currently three high level KBase APIs for specific data types: * The GenomeAnnotation API provides methods to retrieve data from genome annotations in KBase. * The Assembly API provides methods to retrieve data for genome assemblies in KBase. * The Taxon API provides methods to retrieve data for taxa in KBase. Data objects can also be accessed through a generic object API. Future KBase development efforts will be targeting additional data types. Setting up the Data API ----

Example of using a KBase Data API: retrieving all proteins from a GenomeAnnotation
----

Example of using a KBase Data API: retrieving all contig ids for an Assembly
----

Example of using a KBase Data API: retrieving taxonomic id and scientific lineage for a Taxon
----

KBase Data API example narratives --- * Simple, complete example narrative using a KBase Data API client * A narrative with more examples of using a KBase Data API client * Quality plots for genome sequence data * GenomeAnnotation object comparison table * Simple example narrative using a KBase Data API library
