import os
token = os.environ["KB_AUTH_TOKEN"]

# these are for client-server communication
from doekbase.data_api.annotation.genome_annotation.api import GenomeAnnotationClientAPI
from doekbase.data_api.taxonomy.taxon.api import TaxonClientAPI
from doekbase.data_api.sequence.assembly.api import AssemblyClientAPI
# the ObjectClientAPI is not ready yet, coming soon

taxonurl='https://ci.kbase.us/services/data/taxon'
assemblyurl='https://ci.kbase.us/services/data/assembly'
genomeannotationurl='https://ci.kbase.us/services/data/annotation'

# an example Arabidopsis KBase reference genome
ref='2844/12'

annoapi = GenomeAnnotationClientAPI(genomeannotationurl, token, ref)
# this can take a while
proteins = annoapi.get_proteins()
# you will need a proper key or can loop over proteins.keys()
# (don't print entire structure, quite large)
print proteins['AEE33781.1']

# obtain an Assembly Workspace reference
assemblyref = annoapi.get_assembly()
# use the reference to instantiate an AssemblyAPI object
assemblyapi = AssemblyClientAPI(assemblyurl, token, assemblyref)

contig_ids = assemblyapi.get_contig_ids()
print contig_ids

# obtain a Workspace reference
taxonref = annoapi.get_taxon()
#  use the reference to instantiate an AssemblyAPI object
taxonapi = TaxonClientAPI(taxonurl, token, taxonref)

# some taxon methods
taxon_id = taxonapi.get_taxonomic_id()
print taxon_id
taxon_lineage = taxonapi.get_scientific_lineage()
print taxon_lineage

code:
# run this cell first to set up appropriate objects

import os

token = os.environ["KB_AUTH_TOKEN"]

# these are for client-server communication
from doekbase.data_api.annotation.genome_annotation.api import GenomeAnnotationClientAPI
from doekbase.data_api.taxonomy.taxon.api import TaxonClientAPI
from doekbase.data_api.sequence.assembly.api import AssemblyClientAPI
# the ObjectClientAPI is not ready yet, coming soon

taxonurl='https://ci.kbase.us/services/data/taxon'
assemblyurl='https://ci.kbase.us/services/data/assembly'
genomeannotationurl='https://ci.kbase.us/services/data/genome_annotation'

# hard-coded workspace reference for now, an arabidopsis genome
ref='2844/12'

annoapi = GenomeAnnotationClientAPI(genomeannotationurl, token, ref)
# this can take a while
proteins = annoapi.get_proteins()
# you will need a proper key or can loop over proteins.keys()
# (don't print entire structure, quite large)
print proteins['AEE33781.1']

rrna_ids = annoapi.get_feature_ids(filters={"type_list": ["rRNA"]})
print rrna_ids

features = annoapi.get_features(rrna_ids["by_type"]["rRNA"])
print features

# returns another workspace ref
assemblyref = annoapi.get_assembly()
# take the ref to generate an assembly object
assemblyapi = AssemblyClientAPI(assemblyurl, token, assemblyref)

contig_ids = assemblyapi.get_contig_ids()
print contig_ids

contigs = assemblyapi.get_contigs()
# these ids are specific to the arabidopsis genome
print contigs['CP002685'].keys()
print contigs['CP002685']['description']
# sequence will of course be quite long

annos = assemblyapi.get_genome_annotations()
# this will be a list of references to all genome annotations that reference this assembly
# can use GenomeAnnotationClientAPI to make python objects to interact with them
print annos

# returns another workspace ref
taxonref = annoapi.get_taxon()
# take the ref to generate a taxon object
taxonapi = TaxonClientAPI(taxonurl, token, taxonref)

# some taxon methods
taxon_id = taxonapi.get_taxonomic_id()
print taxon_id
taxon_lineage = taxonapi.get_scientific_lineage()
print taxon_lineage

genome_annotations = taxonapi.get_genome_annotations()
# this is a list of genome annotation references
# you can use GenomeAnnotationClientAPI to make python objects to interact with these
# annotations (so you can start from a taxon instead of a genome)
print genome_annotations

taxonref = annoapi.get_taxon()
# take the ref to generate a taxon object
taxonapi = TaxonClientAPI(taxonurl, token, taxonref)

# some taxon methods
taxon_id = taxonapi.get_taxonomic_id()
print taxon_id
taxon_lineage = taxonapi.get_scientific_lineage()
print taxon_lineage

genome_annotations = taxonapi.get_genome_annotations()
# this is a list of genome annotation references
# you can use GenomeAnnotationClientAPI to make python objects to interact with these
# annotations (so you can start from a taxon instead of a genome)
print genome_annotations

markdown: ![KBase Logo](/wp-content/uploads/2014/11/kbase-logo-web.png) Welcome to the Narrative Interface! === What's a Narrative? --- Design and carry out collaborative computational experiments while creating Narratives: interactive, shareable, and reproducible records of your data, computational steps, and thought processes. learn more... Get Some Data --- Click the Add Data button in the Data Panel to browse for KBase data or upload your own. Mouse over a data object to add it to your Narrative, and check out more details once the data appears in your list. learn more... Analyze It --- Browse available analyses that can be run using KBase apps or methods (apps are just multi-step methods that make some common analyses more convenient). Select an analysis, fill in the fields, and click Run. Output will be generated, and new data objects will be created and added to your data list. Add to your results by running follow-on apps or methods. learn more... Save and Share Your Narrative --- Be sure to save your Narrative frequently. When you're ready, click the share button above to let collaborators view your analysis steps and results. Or better yet, make your Narrative public and help expand the social web that KBase is building to make systems biology research open, collaborative, and more effective. learn more... Find Documentation and Help --- For more information, please see the Narrative Interface User Guide or the app/method tutorials. Questions? Contact us! Ready to begin adding to your Narrative? You can keep this Welcome cell or delete it with the trash icon in the top right corner.

import os
token = os.environ["KB_AUTH_TOKEN"]

# these are for client-server communication
from doekbase.data_api.annotation.genome_annotation.api import GenomeAnnotationClientAPI
from doekbase.data_api.taxonomy.taxon.api import TaxonClientAPI
from doekbase.data_api.sequence.assembly.api import AssemblyClientAPI

# the ObjectClientAPI is not ready yet, coming soon

taxonurl='https://ci.kbase.us/services/data/taxon'
assemblyurl='https://ci.kbase.us/services/data/assembly'
genomeannotationurl='https://ci.kbase.us/services/data/annotation'





# hard-coded workspace reference for arabidopsis ensemble genome
ref='4435/26/2'
annoapi = GenomeAnnotationClientAPI(genomeannotationurl, token, ref)


#Get taxon information 
# obtain a Workspace reference
taxonref = annoapi.get_taxon()
#  use the reference to instantiate an AssemblyAPI object
taxonapi = TaxonClientAPI(taxonurl, token, taxonref)


#Get assembly information
#Find the assembly version used to generate this annotation
assembly=annoapi.get_assembly()
# obtain an Assembly Workspace reference
assemblyref = annoapi.get_assembly()
# use the reference to instantiate an AssemblyAPI object
assemblyapi = AssemblyClientAPI(assemblyurl, token, assemblyref)


# Get taxonomic classification 
taxon_id = taxonapi.get_taxonomic_id()
print taxon_id
taxon_lineage = taxonapi.get_scientific_lineage()
print taxon_lineage
#Get list of contigs in the genome
print "\n\nList of contigs\n"
print assemblyapi.get_contig_ids()

print "\n\nMetadata of all contigs\n"
contig_ids = assemblyapi.get_contig_ids()
#mitochondria_id = contig_ids[3]

#There is status 404 for the node.. and most probably the node doesn't exist.. 
#Otherwise this could be used to download contigset
for contig in contig_ids:
   print assemblyapi.get_contigs([contig])
   print
    

   
#Find features types in genome
print annoapi.get_feature_types()
Proteins = annoapi.get_proteins()
#print ">" + protein_id["alias"] + "\n"
for protein in Proteins:
    protein_data = Proteins["protein_1"]
    print protein_data
    print ">" + " ".join(protein_data['protein_aliases'])
    print protein_data['protein_amino_acid_sequence']
    break
#why doesn't this work
gene_list = annoapi.get_feature_ids(type=['gene'])

#objects

markdown:
# Repos required for kbase-ui:

## Overview

These are the repos currently used by kbase-ui

### The KBase UI web app
- kbase-ui
    - https://github.com/kbase/kbase-ui
    - collaborators: erik, bill

### AMD Packages
AMD packages are collections of AMD modules. They are packaged into namespaced directories with a structure like:
```
kb/PACKAGE/MODULE
```
This allows them to be integrated into the kbase-ui module tree without any special configuration. They are loaded by the module string "kb/PACKAGE/MODULE". E.g. *kb/common/html* loads the html utility module.

Each repo, which I refer to as a package, is given a verbose name, prefixed with *kbase-*. This is because they are each registered in the *Bower* and sometimes *NPM* registries. This is required in order to use semver-capable tools for specifying dependencies. In each case, the name registered with the service is also the repo name. Even though this may not be strictly necessary, it is much easier to manage them if the names are the same. Since the names are global, the *kbase-* prefix should make for unique package names. (This is debatable, since there is a kbase product which has been around for much longer that KBase has, although they don't appear to be in the Javscript business.)

- kbase-common-js
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-common-js
    - kbase org repo: exists (need to replace)
    - utility modules and subsystems which are or can be shared across javascript projects
- kbase-service-clients-js
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-service-clients-js
    - kbase org repo: need
    - clients for kbase services, bundled modules of such, and utility classes.
    - updated by hand when there are service client updates.
    - client updates are wrapped in js "promises" for easier and uniform codig in the ui or other apps
- kbase-ui-widget
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-ui-widget
    - kbase org repo: need
    - widget base objects, widget managers, and legacy widget bases
- kbase-data-api-client-js
     - https://github.com/kbase/kbase-data-api-client-js
     - the data api thrift client wrappers; also includes all of the thrift dependencies
- kbase-data-thrift-clients
    - https://github.com/kbase/kbase-data-thrift-clients
    - the clients generated by the data api thrift project (all languages)
- kbase-data-thrift-js
    - https://github.com/kbase/kbase-data-thrift-js
    - thrift javascript support, provides binary protocol, xhr transport

### KBase UI Plugins
All widgets in kbase-ui are loaded via *plugins*. A plugin is a collection of configuration, javascript, and resources contained under a single directory and utilizing a specific directory structure and file naming convention. Widgets can provide modules, widgets, type mapping to widgets, routes, and menu items (which do not automatically appear, but are available for the ui.)

Many widgets are built into kbase ui. E.g. the layout, menu, login widget, login panel, user profile. However, larger widgets, those which are anticipated to be candidates for wholesale replacement, and those which may be utilized in more than one app (e.g. Narrative) are contained in separate plugin repos. A plugin repo is not much more than the plugin itself, although importantly they contain a bower.json configuration file required for installation.

Ideally they each will contain a test suite which can be run independently of kbase-ui, and can be developed in an isolated widget development tool, but at the moment the development process requires that they be loaded and iterated over within a local copy of kbase-ui.

It should be noted that a plugin can contain any arbitrary javascript code. Some of it may be loaded only within the local modules (e.g. utilities or special libraries), but there is a mechanism for making the code available globally with the host app. Widgets themselves are loaded into a special widget manager, although the code itself is technically provided as an AMD module.

- kbase-ui-plugin-vis-widgets
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-ui-plugin-vis-widgets
    - kbase org repo: need
    - provides: widgets
    - Jim's vis widgets; other than demo pages, I don't think these are in actual use in the ui, although there are widgets in Narrative which use them.
- kbase-ui-plugin-typeview
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-ui-plugin-typeview
    - kbase org repo: need
    - provides: menu item, route, panel, widget
    - Widgets supporting the viewing of types 
- kbase-ui-plugin-dataview
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-ui-plugin-dataview
    - kbase org repo: exists (need to replace)
    - provides: menu item, route, panel, widget
    - Widgets supporting the "landing page", called dataview within the app, and the original set of data viewing widgets. 
- kbase-ui-plugin-dashboard
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-ui-plugin-dashboard
    - kbase org repo: exists (need to replace)
    - provides: menu item, route, panel, widgets
    - The main dashboard view in kbase-ui. A separate repo due to size, complexity, and the fact that it probably (or at least should) be refactored. It is trivial to swap out one plugin for a replacement one, so refactoring plugins is one of the main use cases.
- kbase-ui-plugin-datawidgets
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-ui-plugin-datawidgets.git
    - kbaes org repo: need
    - provides: widgets
    - This was a seminal effort at refactoring dataview widgets. Just a few were ported over. They work, but are in various states of exploration for widget api ideas. 
- kbase-ui-plugin-methodview
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-ui-plugin-methodview.git
    - kbase org repo: need
    - provides: route, panel, widgets
    - For viewing method "man pages" for legacy methods. At present it passes through methods to the appcatalog, and shows a view for apps.
- kbase-ui-plugin-data-landing-pages
    - https://github.com/kbase/kbase-ui-plugin-data-landing-pages
    - provides: widgets
    - new data view widgets created for the data api. This is brand new and actively developed by the data api team.

### Development Plugins
There is a collection of plugins supplying tools useful for development. It is also a model for how developers can utlize their own development plugins in order to provide system exploration, introspection, prototyping, etc.

I don't know if any of these need to litter the kbase repo space. Perhaps there is a kbase developer repo that would be more suitable?

- kbase-ui-plugin-typeview
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-ui-plugin-typeview.git
    - provides: menu item, route, panel, widget
    - A simple datatable-based view of all types registered in the current workspace deployment (depends on the kbase-ui build). This is very useful for testing typeview. In addition, each type-row has a browse link which brings up a dataview with the type filtered.
- kbase-ui-plugin-dataview    
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-ui-plugin-dataview.git
    - provides: menu item, route, panel, widget
    - A simple datatable-based presentation of all objects the current user has access to. Very useful in combination with the typeview, as it takes a type parameter for filtering (and will query workspace with this type). Each object-row has a link to typeview for the type and dataview for the object. This is a critical tool for dataview testing.
- kbase-ui-plugin-jobbrowser
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-ui-plugin-jobbrowser.git
    - provides: menu item, route, panel, widget
    - A simple table of all jobs accessible to the current user as reported by the UJS service for the current deployment environment. It was put together to assist in debugging the dataview downloader, to be able to monitor the status transform jobs.
- kbase-ui-plugin-shockbrowser
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-ui-plugin-shockbrowser.git
    - provides: menu item, route, panel, widget    
    - A simple table view of all files reported by the shock client. Also developed for debugging of the dataview download tool
- kbase-ui-plugin-data-api-demo
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-ui-plugin-data-api-demo.git
    - provides: menu item, route, panel, widget    
    - This widget lists all accessible data objects for types compatible with the data api. Each found object provides a link, which invokes a simple table rendering of all known methods/properties of an api call relevant to the given object. Useful for debugging the data api, and esp. for inspecting a variety of objects of different types and versions.
- kbase-ui-plugin-demo-vis-widget
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-ui-plugin-demo-vis-widget.git
    - provides: menu items, routes, panels, widgets     
    - Useful for esting several of Jim's vis widgets. Good for testing that these widgets haven't been broken; should be expanded to cover all widgets; in the future should be updated to reflect standardized types accepted by the widgets, and also to serve as automated ui testing endpoints.
data.title: KBase UI Repos

markdown:
# Repos required for kbase-ui:

## Overview

These are the repos currently used by kbase-ui

### The KBase UI web app
- kbase-ui
    - https://github.com/kbase/kbase-ui
    - collaborators: erik, bill

### AMD Packages
AMD packages are collections of AMD modules. They are packaged into namespaced directories with a structure like:
```
kb/PACKAGE/MODULE
```
This allows them to be integrated into the kbase-ui module tree without any special configuration. They are loaded by the module string "kb/PACKAGE/MODULE". E.g. *kb/common/html* loads the html utility module.

Each repo, which I refer to as a package, is given a verbose name, prefixed with *kbase-*. This is because they are each registered in the *Bower* and sometimes *NPM* registries. This is required in order to use semver-capable tools for specifying dependencies. In each case, the name registered with the service is also the repo name. Even though this may not be strictly necessary, it is much easier to manage them if the names are the same. Since the names are global, the *kbase-* prefix should make for unique package names. (This is debatable, since there is a kbase product which has been around for much longer that KBase has, although they don't appear to be in the Javscript business.)

- kbase-common-js
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-common-js
    - kbase org repo: exists (need to replace)
    - utility modules and subsystems which are or can be shared across javascript projects
- kbase-service-clients-js
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-service-clients-js
    - kbase org repo: need
    - clients for kbase services, bundled modules of such, and utility classes.
    - updated by hand when there are service client updates.
    - client updates are wrapped in js "promises" for easier and uniform codig in the ui or other apps
- kbase-ui-widget
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-ui-widget
    - kbase org repo: need
    - widget base objects, widget managers, and legacy widget bases
- kbase-data-api-client-js
     - https://github.com/kbase/kbase-data-api-client-js
     - the data api thrift client wrappers; also includes all of the thrift dependencies
- kbase-data-thrift-clients
    - https://github.com/kbase/kbase-data-thrift-clients
    - the clients generated by the data api thrift project (all languages)
- kbase-data-thrift-js
    - https://github.com/kbase/kbase-data-thrift-js
    - thrift javascript support, provides binary protocol, xhr transport

### KBase UI Plugins
All widgets in kbase-ui are loaded via *plugins*. A plugin is a collection of configuration, javascript, and resources contained under a single directory and utilizing a specific directory structure and file naming convention. Widgets can provide modules, widgets, type mapping to widgets, routes, and menu items (which do not automatically appear, but are available for the ui.)

Many widgets are built into kbase ui. E.g. the layout, menu, login widget, login panel, user profile. However, larger widgets, those which are anticipated to be candidates for wholesale replacement, and those which may be utilized in more than one app (e.g. Narrative) are contained in separate plugin repos. A plugin repo is not much more than the plugin itself, although importantly they contain a bower.json configuration file required for installation.

Ideally they each will contain a test suite which can be run independently of kbase-ui, and can be developed in an isolated widget development tool, but at the moment the development process requires that they be loaded and iterated over within a local copy of kbase-ui.

It should be noted that a plugin can contain any arbitrary javascript code. Some of it may be loaded only within the local modules (e.g. utilities or special libraries), but there is a mechanism for making the code available globally with the host app. Widgets themselves are loaded into a special widget manager, although the code itself is technically provided as an AMD module.

- kbase-ui-plugin-vis-widgets
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-ui-plugin-vis-widgets
    - kbase org repo: need
    - provides: widgets
    - Jim's vis widgets; other than demo pages, I don't think these are in actual use in the ui, although there are widgets in Narrative which use them.
- kbase-ui-plugin-typeview
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-ui-plugin-typeview
    - kbase org repo: need
    - provides: menu item, route, panel, widget
    - Widgets supporting the viewing of types 
- kbase-ui-plugin-dataview
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-ui-plugin-dataview
    - kbase org repo: exists (need to replace)
    - provides: menu item, route, panel, widget
    - Widgets supporting the "landing page", called dataview within the app, and the original set of data viewing widgets. 
- kbase-ui-plugin-dashboard
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-ui-plugin-dashboard
    - kbase org repo: exists (need to replace)
    - provides: menu item, route, panel, widgets
    - The main dashboard view in kbase-ui. A separate repo due to size, complexity, and the fact that it probably (or at least should) be refactored. It is trivial to swap out one plugin for a replacement one, so refactoring plugins is one of the main use cases.
- kbase-ui-plugin-datawidgets
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-ui-plugin-datawidgets.git
    - kbaes org repo: need
    - provides: widgets
    - This was a seminal effort at refactoring dataview widgets. Just a few were ported over. They work, but are in various states of exploration for widget api ideas. 
- kbase-ui-plugin-methodview
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-ui-plugin-methodview.git
    - kbase org repo: need
    - provides: route, panel, widgets
    - For viewing method "man pages" for legacy methods. At present it passes through methods to the appcatalog, and shows a view for apps.
- kbase-ui-plugin-data-landing-pages
    - https://github.com/kbase/kbase-ui-plugin-data-landing-pages
    - provides: widgets
    - new data view widgets created for the data api. This is brand new and actively developed by the data api team.

### Development Plugins
There is a collection of plugins supplying tools useful for development. It is also a model for how developers can utlize their own development plugins in order to provide system exploration, introspection, prototyping, etc.

I don't know if any of these need to litter the kbase repo space. Perhaps there is a kbase developer repo that would be more suitable?

- kbase-ui-plugin-typeview
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-ui-plugin-typeview.git
    - provides: menu item, route, panel, widget
    - A simple datatable-based view of all types registered in the current workspace deployment (depends on the kbase-ui build). This is very useful for testing typeview. In addition, each type-row has a browse link which brings up a dataview with the type filtered.
- kbase-ui-plugin-dataview    
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-ui-plugin-dataview.git
    - provides: menu item, route, panel, widget
    - A simple datatable-based presentation of all objects the current user has access to. Very useful in combination with the typeview, as it takes a type parameter for filtering (and will query workspace with this type). Each object-row has a link to typeview for the type and dataview for the object. This is a critical tool for dataview testing.
- kbase-ui-plugin-jobbrowser
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-ui-plugin-jobbrowser.git
    - provides: menu item, route, panel, widget
    - A simple table of all jobs accessible to the current user as reported by the UJS service for the current deployment environment. It was put together to assist in debugging the dataview downloader, to be able to monitor the status transform jobs.
- kbase-ui-plugin-shockbrowser
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-ui-plugin-shockbrowser.git
    - provides: menu item, route, panel, widget    
    - A simple table view of all files reported by the shock client. Also developed for debugging of the dataview download tool
- kbase-ui-plugin-data-api-demo
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-ui-plugin-data-api-demo.git
    - provides: menu item, route, panel, widget    
    - This widget lists all accessible data objects for types compatible with the data api. Each found object provides a link, which invokes a simple table rendering of all known methods/properties of an api call relevant to the given object. Useful for debugging the data api, and esp. for inspecting a variety of objects of different types and versions.
- kbase-ui-plugin-demo-vis-widget
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-ui-plugin-demo-vis-widget.git
    - provides: menu items, routes, panels, widgets     
    - Useful for esting several of Jim's vis widgets. Good for testing that these widgets haven't been broken; should be expanded to cover all widgets; in the future should be updated to reflect standardized types accepted by the widgets, and also to serve as automated ui testing endpoints.

markdown:
### Arabidopsis wild and mutant studies 

### Study: Genome-wide mapping of the HY5-mediated gene networks in Arabidopsis that involve both transcriptional and post-transcriptional regulations: RNA-Seq

LONG HYPOCOTYL 5 (HY5) is a basic leucine zipper transcription factor (TF) that functions downstream of multiple families of photoreceptors. Mutations in the HY5 gene cause a number of changes in phenotypes in Arabidopsis, including elongated hypocotyl, reduced accumulation of pigments, halted chloroplast development in greening hypocotyls, altered root morphology and defective hormonal and stimulus responses. HY5 thus acts as an integrator that links various gene networks to coordinate plant development. 

#### Data Description:

Published data from NCBI Sequence Read Archive study SRP003951 is used for this study. It includes four sample files that have two treatments (wild and mutant) with two replicates each for the treatments. All reads are derived from Illumina Genome Analyzer (singe-end reads). These read files are filtered, trimmed and generated in fastq files. The fastq filese are imported using "Import" to Data Pane. 

#### Ath_WT_rep1.fastq - SRR70570 WT RNA-seq replicate 1
#### Ath_WT_rep2.fastq - SRR70571 WT RNA-seq replicate 2
#### Ath_hy5_rep1.fastq - SRR70572 hy5 RNA-seq replicate 1
#### Ath_hy5_rep2.fastq - SRR70573 hy5 RNA-seq replicate 2

### Steps in this Narrative + **Step 1:** Import Reads, Contigs set (FASTA), Reference Genome Annotation (GTF) + **Step 2:** Build Bowtie2 Index + **Step 3:** Set up RNA-seq analysis + **Step 4:** Align Reads using Tophat + **Step 5:** Assemble Transcripts with Cufflinks + **Step 6:** Merge Transcripts using Cuffmerge + **Step 7:** Identify Differential Expression using Cuffdiff + **Step 8:** Create CummeRbund Plots + **Step 9:** View Expression Matrix Heatmap + **Step 10:** Create Expression Matrix + **Step 11:** Cluster Expression Data - WGCNA

code:
import doekbase.data_api
from doekbase.data_api.taxonomy.taxon.api import TaxonClientAPI
from doekbase.data_api.annotation.genome_annotation.api import GenomeAnnotationClientAPI
from doekbase.data_api.sequence.assembly.api import AssemblyClientAPI
from doekbase.workspace.client import Workspace

services = {
    "taxon_service_url": "https://ci.kbase.us/services/data/taxon/",
    "assembly_service_url": "https://ci.kbase.us/services/data/assembly/",
    "genome_annotation_service_url": "https://ci.kbase.us/services/data/genome_annotation/"
}

import os
token = os.environ["KB_AUTH_TOKEN"]

ws = Workspace(url="https://ci.kbase.us/services/ws/", token=token)

workspace_names = ["ReferenceEnsemblPlantGenomeAnnotations", 
                   "ReferenceGenomeAnnotations", 
                   "OriginalReferenceGenomes"]
landing_page_prefix = "https://narrative-ci.kbase.us/#/dataview/"
annotation_info = {}

for name in workspace_names:
    annotations = ws.list_objects({"workspaces": [name], "type": "KBaseGenomeAnnotations.GenomeAnnotation"})
    genomes = ws.list_objects({"workspaces": [name], "type": "KBaseGenomes.Genome"})    
    annotations.extend(genomes)
    
    for obj in annotations:
        ref = obj[7] + "/" + obj[1]
        print ref
        ga = GenomeAnnotationClientAPI(services["genome_annotation_service_url"],token,ref)
        taxon = TaxonClientAPI(services["taxon_service_url"],token,ga.get_taxon())
        annotation_info[obj[7] + "/" + obj[1]] = {
            "bytes": obj[-2], 
            "landing_page": landing_page_prefix + ref,
            "scientific_name": taxon.get_scientific_name()
        }

alpha_sort = sorted(annotation_info, key=lambda x: annotation_info[x]["scientific_name"])

for x in alpha_sort:
    print "{}\t{}".format(annotation_info[x]["scientific_name"], 
                          annotation_info[x]["landing_page"])

markdown:
ENIGMA-KBase integration project: Metals Metabolism use cases
---


This narrative is amied to demostrate methods, mehtod inputs, and widgets developed in a course of the ENIGMA-KBase integration project.

Data for testing provided by Mike Adams and Romy Chacraborty teams.

Three data types are supported: 1) Growth data, 2) Sample-property data, 3) Chromatography data

Growth data
===

GrowthMatrix type is designed to support growth data. Three objects are uploaded into this narrative to represent different types of data comlexity: 

1. gowth-nickel-series - small assay, the concentration of only one substance is varied
2. N2E2_carbon_sources_nitrate_growth - small assay, the concentration of two substences is varied at the same time
2. 2014-06-19_Mo_W_titration - large multidimensional assay, the concnetration of two substances and strains are varied

Let us start from the simple assay...

**Overview tab** provides the general metadata about the growth data object. Any metadata from the uploaded input file will be shown here. 

**Sammray tab** provies summary info about samples, series, conditions and time points 

**Samples and Series tabs:**  the growth data object has samples that can be grouped into series. Basic parameters like max achived OD and max instantenious growth rate are caulcated on fly and shown in these tabs. User can sort by any of these parameters to get some initial sense of the data. *Series* tab provides info about series - grouped samples (replicas). OD values are first averaged and then "Max OD" and "Max rate" are calculated.


**In this example** there are 10 samples, and 5 series (2 replicas per series)
I would like to look at the growht curves for series

If I click on the [Show/Hide Series], I will see the details about the selected series. I see that the fastest and slowest growing conditions are Nickel 5um (S3) and 0um (S1).  

I would like to see growth curves for these two conditions, visualize error bars and show them in the log scale

Can I look at the growht curves for the actual samples (replicas)? Yes. 

For instance, I am interested in growth curves for series S3, just want to plot them and compare.

We wil do it in two steps:  
1. Find the smaple ids corresponding to S3
2. Plot growth curves for these sample ids
Let us once again view the growth matrix.

If we go to Samples tab, and filter by S3 we will see that this series is comprised from two samples C5 and C6.

Let us visualize growth curves for samples C5 and C6
I would like to caluclate growth parameters for all samples and series in this growth data object. I will use "Fit Growth Curve" method to do that.

Great! I can see estimates for four growth parameters: growth rate, max growth, lag phase, and area under curve.

**Sample growth parameters:** these are values caulcated by grofit R package using "spline" mehtod.   

**Series growth parameters:** first the values are calculated by gorfit, and then the values are grouped into series. Average and SE are caluclated for each series and reported on this tab.
I would like to see the dose-response curve for one of these parameters

The desciption of a condition for a given sample can be more complex and include several parametrs. GrowthMatrix type allows to do that. Here is an example of the experimenet where sveral pair of substances and concetrations and their effect on the growth are studied.
And here is even more complicated case: two substances and strain are varied.

So many data in this object... I would like to look at the growth curves only for three fastest and two slowest samples. I can easliy find them on the Samples tab  by sorting by Max rate parameter.  

The samples are C4, C18, C16 and C90, C191

Chromatography data
===


We uploaded two chromatography data objects. Let us look at them

For each substance, the peaks are identified on fly, and max value and the corresponding time are reported.

We can also look at the chromatograms.
And here is another chromatography data generated by the ENIGMA Metals metabolism campaign

Sample-propeties data
===

We have ENIGMA 100-wells survey results. We uploaded them as a SamplePropertyMatrix object.

**Overview tab** provides the general metadata about the data object. Any metadata from the input file will be shown here. 

**Sammray tab** provies summary info about samples and properties

**Samples tab**  shows the list of samples (in this case wells). For each sample (well) the max and min values calculated across all properties (metals).

**Sample properties tab** shows the list of properties (in this case metals). The average, STD, and SE are caluclated acorss all samples (wells).


Sorting by "Average" I can see the most abundant metal acorss all wells: Mn and Fe.

But now I would like to get more detailed info. For instance, I can select two or more wells and compare them.
Or we can select two properties (metals) and see how their values are distributed across all samples (wells)
data.title: ENIGMA Metals use cases v2

# Lots o' code.
Execute the first few cells to get those functions in memory.
### Examples of running stuff goes below.
code:
# imports. run this first!

from biokbase.NarrativeJobService.Client import NarrativeJobService
from biokbase.narrative.common.url_config import URLS
from biokbase.workspace.client import Workspace
from biokbase.narrative_method_store.client import NarrativeMethodStore
from IPython.core.magic import register_line_magic
import os
import re
import json

def get_system_variable(var):
    """
    Returns a KBase system variable. Just a little wrapper.
    options:
        workspace - returns the KBase workspace name
        token - returns the current user's token credential
    
    if anything is not found, returns None
    """
    var = var.lower()
    if var == 'workspace':
        return os.environ.get('KB_WORKSPACE_ID', None)
    elif var == 'token':
        return os.environ.get('KB_AUTH_TOKEN', None)

def kb_run_method(method_id, version="release", **kwargs):
    """
    Runs a method programmatically and returns the running job id.
    ONLY WORKS FOR SDK-created METHODS!
    
    * method_id = the fully qualified method id (you can find these with %kb list_methods)
    * version (default=release) = the version of that method, either release, beta, or dev
    
    the remaining keyword args are specific for each method. These can be found with
    %kb method_info
    """
    # 1. get method spec
    nms = NarrativeMethodStore(URLS.narrative_method_store)
    try:
        spec = nms.get_method_spec({'ids': [method_id], 'tag': version})[0]
    except:
        raise

    # 2. reconcile parameters, check that the right ones are there.
    input_vals = dict()
    if not spec.has_key('behavior') or not spec['behavior'].has_key('kb_service_input_mapping'):
        raise Exception("Only good for SDK-made methods!")
    for param in spec['behavior']['kb_service_input_mapping']:
        p_value = None
        p_id = None
        if 'input_parameter' in param:
            p_id = param['input_parameter']
            p_value = kwargs.get(p_id, None)
        elif 'narrative_system_variable' in param:
            p_id = param['narrative_system_variable']
            p_value = get_system_variable(p_id)
        input_vals[p_id] = p_value

    method_name = spec['behavior']['kb_service_method']
    service_name = spec['behavior']['kb_service_name']
    service_ver = spec['behavior']['kb_service_version']
    service_url = spec['behavior']['kb_service_url']
    # 3. set up app structure
    app = {'name': 'App wrapper for method ' + method_id,
           'steps': [{'input_values': [input_vals],
                      'is_long_running': 1,
                      'method_spec_id': method_id,
                      'script': {'has_files': 0, 'method_name': '', 'service_name': ''},
                      'service': {'method_name': method_name,
                                  'service_name': service_name,
                                  'service_url': service_url,
                                  'service_version': service_ver},
                      'step_id': method_id,
                      'type': 'service'}]}
    
    njs = NarrativeJobService(URLS.job_service, token=get_system_variable('token'))
    app_state = njs.run_app(app)
    print "Starting app with the following info:"
    pprint(app_state)
    return KBaseJob(app_state)

def kb_output_widget(widget_name, input_data): """ renders a widget! """ from IPython.display import Javascript from jinja2 import Template import json import uuid import time input_template = """ element.html("
"); require(['kbaseNarrativeOutputCell', '{{widget_name}}'], function() { $('#{{input_id}}').kbaseNarrativeOutputCell({"data": {{input_data}}, "type":"method", "widget": "{{widget_name}}", "cellId": "{{input_id}}", "title": "{{cell_title}}", "time": {{timestamp}} }); }); """ js = Template(input_template).render(input_id=uuid.uuid4(), widget_name=widget_name, input_data=input_data, #json.dumps(input_data), cell_title="Title Goes Here", timestamp=int(round(time.time()*1000))) return Javascript(data=js, lib=None, css=None)

#ws = Workspace('https://ci.kbase.us/services/ws')
#ws.list_objects({'workspaces': [get_system_variable('workspace')], 'type': 'KBaseGenomes.Genome'})

%kb list_data
%kb method_info fba_tools/build_metabolic_model dev

kb_show_widget('kbaseTabTable',
               {'type':'KBaseFBA.FBAModel',
                'ws': 'wjriehl:1456453274563',
                'obj':'Arabidopsis_gapfilled'})

kb_output_widget('kbaseTabTable',
               {'type':'KBaseFBA.FBAModel',
                'ws': 'wjriehl:1456453274563',
                'obj':'yersinia_model'})
%kb method_info fba_tools/build_metabolic_model dev

my_job = kb_run_method("fba_tools/build_metabolic_model",
    version="dev",
    genome_id="Rhodobacter_sphaeroides_2.4.1_KBase",
    fbamodel_output_id="test_rhodo_model3",
    minimum_target_flux=100,
    gapfill_model=0)
my_job.status_detail()['original_app']['steps'][0]['method_spec_id']
%kb list_methods dev
model = %kb get_data yersinia_model
spec = %kb get_method fba_tools/build_metabolic_model dev
pprint(spec['behavior'])

run_method('MsneddonContigFilter/filter_contigs', 
           contigset_id="rhodo_contigs", 
           min_length=100)
my_job.status_detail()
%kb get_method fba_tools/build_metabolic_model dev
a = %kb get_data Phosphate-Phospho-Glycolic-Acid

# Hunk of JSON that gets sent to NJS for running jobs.

import json
x = json.loads('{"steps": [{"service": {"method_name": "filter_contigs", "service_name": "MsneddonContigFilter", "service_url": "", "service_version": "10100999595c9031e51a877a8a278d2e06583f3a"}, "script": {"method_name": "", "service_name": "", "has_files": 0}, "method_spec_id": "MsneddonContigFilter/filter_contigs", "input_values": [{"contigset_id": "rhodo_contigs", "min_length": "100", "workspace": "wjriehl:1456453274563"}], "step_id": "MsneddonContigFilter/filter_contigs", "type": "service", "is_long_running": 1}], "name": "App wrapper for method MsneddonContigFilter/filter_contigs"}')

import time
int(round(time.time()*1000))

    if var == 'workspace':
        return os.environ.get('KB_WORKSPACE_ID', None)
    elif var == 'token':
        return os.environ.get('KB_AUTH_TOKEN', None)

def kb_run_method(method_id, version="release", **kwargs):
    """
    Runs a method programmatically and returns the running job id.
    ONLY WORKS FOR SDK-created METHODS!
    
    * method_id = the fully qualified method id (you can find these with %kb list_methods)
    * version (default=release) = the version of that method, either release, beta, or dev
    
    the remaining keyword args are specific for each method. These can be found with
    %kb method_info
    """
    # 1. get method spec
    nms = NarrativeMethodStore(URLS.narrative_method_store)
    try:
        spec = nms.get_method_spec({'ids': [method_id], 'tag': version})[0]
    except:
        raise

    # 2. reconcile parameters, check that the right ones are there.
    input_vals = dict()
    if not spec.has_key('behavior') or not spec['behavior'].has_key('kb_service_input_mapping'):
        raise Exception("Only good for SDK-made methods!")
    for param in spec['behavior']['kb_service_input_mapping']:
        p_value = None
        p_id = None
        if 'input_parameter' in param:
            p_id = param['input_parameter']
            p_value = kwargs.get(p_id, None)
        elif 'narrative_system_variable' in param:
            p_id = param['narrative_system_variable']
            p_value = get_system_variable(p_id)
        input_vals[p_id] = p_value

    method_name = spec['behavior']['kb_service_method']
    service_name = spec['behavior']['kb_service_name']
    service_ver = spec['behavior']['kb_service_version']
    service_url = spec['behavior']['kb_service_url']
    # 3. set up app structure
    app = {'name': 'App wrapper for method ' + method_id,
           'steps': [{'input_values': [input_vals],
                      'is_long_running': 1,
                      'method_spec_id': method_id,
                      'script': {'has_files': 0, 'method_name': '', 'service_name': ''},
                      'service': {'method_name': method_name,
                                  'service_name': service_name,
                                  'service_url': service_url,
                                  'service_version': service_ver},
                      'step_id': method_id,
                      'type': 'service'}]}
    
    njs = NarrativeJobService(URLS.job_service, token=get_system_variable('token'))
    app_state = njs.run_app(app)
    print "Starting app with the following info:"
    pprint(app_state)
    return KBaseJob(app_state)

def kb_output_widget(widget_name, input_data): """ renders a widget! """ from IPython.display import Javascript from jinja2 import Template import json import uuid import time input_template = """ element.html("
"); require(['kbaseNarrativeOutputCell', '{{widget_name}}'], function() { $('#{{input_id}}').kbaseNarrativeOutputCell({"data": {{input_data}}, "type":"method", "widget": "{{widget_name}}", "cellId": "{{input_id}}", "title": "{{cell_title}}", "time": {{timestamp}} }); }); """ js = Template(input_template).render(input_id=uuid.uuid4(), widget_name=widget_name, input_data=input_data, #json.dumps(input_data), cell_title="Title Goes Here", timestamp=int(round(time.time()*1000))) return Javascript(data=js, lib=None, css=None)

markdown: ![KBase Logo](http://kbase.us/wp-content/uploads/2014/11/kbase-logo-web.png) Welcome to the Narrative Interface! === What's a Narrative? --- Design and carry out collaborative computational experiments while creating Narratives: interactive, shareable, and reproducible records of your data, computational steps, and thought processes. learn more... Get Some Data --- Click the Add Data button in the Data Panel to browse for KBase data or upload your own. Mouse over a data object to add it to your Narrative, and check out more details once the data appears in your list. learn more... Analyze It --- Browse available analyses that can be run using KBase apps or methods (apps are just multi-step methods that make some common analyses more convenient). Select an analysis, fill in the fields, and click Run. Output will be generated, and new data objects will be created and added to your data list. Add to your results by running follow-on apps or methods. learn more... Save and Share Your Narrative --- Be sure to save your Narrative frequently. When you're ready, click the share button above to let collaborators view your analysis steps and results. Or better yet, make your Narrative public and help expand the social web that KBase is building to make systems biology research open, collaborative, and more effective. learn more... Find Documentation and Help --- For more information, please see the Narrative Interface User Guide or the app/method tutorials. Questions? Contact us! Ready to begin adding to your Narrative? You can keep this Welcome cell or delete it with the trash icon in the top right corner.

markdown: ![KBase Logo](http://kbase.us/wp-content/uploads/2014/11/kbase-logo-web.png) Welcome to the Narrative Interface! === What's a Narrative? --- Design and carry out collaborative computational experiments while creating Narratives: interactive, shareable, and reproducible records of your data, computational steps, and thought processes. learn more... Get Some Data --- Click the Add Data button in the Data Panel to browse for KBase data or upload your own. Mouse over a data object to add it to your Narrative, and check out more details once the data appears in your list. learn more... Analyze It --- Browse available analyses that can be run using KBase apps or methods (apps are just multi-step methods that make some common analyses more convenient). Select an analysis, fill in the fields, and click Run. Output will be generated, and new data objects will be created and added to your data list. Add to your results by running follow-on apps or methods. learn more... Save and Share Your Narrative --- Be sure to save your Narrative frequently. When you're ready, click the share button above to let collaborators view your analysis steps and results. Or better yet, make your Narrative public and help expand the social web that KBase is building to make systems biology research open, collaborative, and more effective. learn more... Find Documentation and Help --- For more information, please see the Narrative Interface User Guide or the app/method tutorials. Questions? Contact us! Ready to begin adding to your Narrative? You can keep this Welcome cell or delete it with the trash icon in the top right corner.

# Notes on nbconvert
The nbconvert docs are pretty useful. That's where I gathered most of below.  
http://nbconvert.readthedocs.org/en/latest/nbconvert_library.html  

It can be run either as a command line tool (which means we need to dump Narratives - repackaged as ipynb files - to some temp space), or as an API. Some API tinkering follows, as a few steps.

# 1. Fetch Narrative typed object.
I go straight to unwrapping the 'data' part of the typed object. This is, in the most recent form, a V4 Jupyter Notebook object.

# 2. Convert to notebook object.
`nbformat` reformats the object as a fancy dict, and does some type checking.
# 3. Load exporter(s)
# 4. Write HTML output. Default directory (local) is /private/tmp/narrative

# 5. Try to export as PDF. Watch it burn. Cry a little.
PDF building on a Mac needs the following installed:

* Pandoc - http://pandoc.org/installing.html
* MacTeX (or, as suggested by Pandoc, BasicTeX) - http://www.tug.org/mactex/morepackages.html
* Once those are installed, need to update a few LaTeX templates with the following commands:

```
sudo tlmgr update --self
sudo tlmgr install adjustbox
sudo tlmgr install collectbox
sudo tlmgr install ucs
```

Then restart your local narrative with all that stuff on your path. Might also need to `pip install pandoc` , I'm not sure (but I did it anyway)

Then run the line below - it'll crash because it can't get the image from the intro markdown to embed. There's something I'm missing here.

After playing with the above stuff up to this point, a few things stand out.

  1. PDF writing is a phenomenal pain in the ass and we shouldn't target that on this sprint - leave it for another one.
  2. Most of our users (and authors) will want some kind of interaction anyway, so HTML output is the way to start.
  3. We will likely need some kind of preprocessor for HTML outputs. Need to support:
    1. Widget code in output areas.
    2. Widget code in MD.
    3. Data lookups / data embedding while not logged in.
    4. Stylesheets.
    5. Possibly embedding JS code itself in the HTML output.
code:
from biokbase.workspace.client import Workspace
ws = Workspace('https://ci.kbase.us/services/ws')
nar = ws.get_objects([{'ref': '6312/1'}])[0]['data']

import nbformat
import json
kb_notebook = nbformat.reads(json.dumps(nar), as_version=4)

from traitlets.config import Config

#1. Import the exporter
from nbconvert import HTMLExporter, PDFExporter

#2. Instantiate the exporters
# html_exporter = HTMLExporter(extra_loaders=[dl])
html_exporter = HTMLExporter()
html_exporter.template_file = 'kbase'


#3. Process the notebook
(body, resources) = html_exporter.from_notebook_node(kb_notebook)
resources['metadata']['title'] = "Super title"
resources['metadata']

with open('test.html', 'w') as output_html:
    output_html.write(body)
kb_pdf = pdf_exporter.from_notebook_node(kb_notebook, notebook_name="test_nb")

print("Resources:", resources.keys())
print("Metadata:", resources['metadata'].keys())
print("Inlining:", resources['inlining'].keys())
print("Extension:", resources['output_extension'])
print("Mimetypes:", resources['raw_mimetypes'])
resources['metadata']['name']

markdown:
# Widget API commands.
Execute the following code cells (shift-enter) down to the **Examples Below** heading. That'll get it started up.

# Widget API Stuff
We need a way to do a few tasks (in no particular order):
  1. Get a widget to load in the output panel
  2. Make that widget aware of its cell, so it can manipulate metadata
  3. Set all KBase Narratives (notebooks) to be forced to be trusted, so they load up that JS always.
  4. Get a list of widgets and their expected inputs.
  5. Map from widget names to expected inputs.
  6. Todo - move this to a biokbase.narrative module

# Examples Below

---

## 1. Fetch all widget info from method specs
Returns a dict with keys for each tag - release, beta, dev  
Under those are keys for each widget name, that's the widget's jQuery name: `'kbaseTabTable'`, `'GenomeAnnotation'`, etc.  
That leads into what should be info for that widget, currently only a `'params'` key.
Each param has the following keys:

  * `is_constant` - boolean. If True, then it has to be present, and will have a preset value.
    * These include user_id, workspace name, and auth token (**note, auth token shouldn't be an input, and should be fetched by the widget's config... we should rework those that do that**)
  * `param_type` - string, one of '`string`', '`int`', '`float`', '`boolean`', '`dropdown`'.  If it's '`dropdown`', it'll have an 'allowed_values' list
  * `param_value` - string, optional - if not null, that's probably a constant value
  * `allowed_values` - list of strings, the values that are allowed in that parameter
  * `allowed_types` - list of strings, these are typed objects that the param is allowed to be.

## 2. Get a widget's inputs
The 'inputs' here are just a human-readable list of what parameters it takes, and some info about them.  
E.g. for the `kbaseTabTable` widget (the FBA model viewer, params above), though it has three parameters, two are constants and taken care of by the viewer invoker. So the user just has to give it `obj`.

## 3. Rendering the widget

That's the `kb_output_widget` command. Just give it the widget name and the inputs it expects, and you'll get the output widget.

Still to-do = rewire the output widget so it hides the inputs and does the icon thing on the side.
code:
# imports. run this first!

from biokbase.NarrativeJobService.Client import NarrativeJobService
from biokbase.narrative.common.url_config import URLS
from biokbase.workspace.client import Workspace
from biokbase.narrative_method_store.client import NarrativeMethodStore
from IPython.core.magic import register_line_magic
import os
import re
import json   
from IPython.display import Javascript
from jinja2 import Template
import uuid
import time
from pprint import pprint

all_widgets = load_all_widget_info()

# show off the params for the FBA model viewer widget
pprint(all_widgets['release']['kbaseTabTable'])

# show a list of all widgets in 'release'
pprint(sorted(all_widgets['release'].keys()))
get_widget_inputs('kbaseTabTable')
kb_output_widget('kbaseTabTable', obj="test_rhodo_model4")
get_widget_inputs('kbaseGenomeView')
kb_output_widget('kbaseGenomeView', id="bsub_annotation")

markdown:
# Lots o' code.
Execute the first few cells to get those functions in memory.
### Examples of running stuff goes below.
code:
# imports. run this first!

from biokbase.NarrativeJobService.Client import NarrativeJobService
from biokbase.narrative.common.url_config import URLS
from biokbase.workspace.client import Workspace
from biokbase.narrative_method_store.client import NarrativeMethodStore
from IPython.core.magic import register_line_magic
import os
import re
import json

def get_system_variable(var):
    """
    Returns a KBase system variable. Just a little wrapper.
    options:
        workspace - returns the KBase workspace name
        token - returns the current user's token credential
    
    if anything is not found, returns None
    """
    var = var.lower()
    if var == 'workspace':
        return os.environ.get('KB_WORKSPACE_ID', None)
    elif var == 'token':
        return os.environ.get('KB_AUTH_TOKEN', None)

def kb_run_method(method_id, version="release", **kwargs):
    """
    Runs a method programmatically and returns the running job id.
    ONLY WORKS FOR SDK-created METHODS!
    
    * method_id = the fully qualified method id (you can find these with %kb list_methods)
    * version (default=release) = the version of that method, either release, beta, or dev
    
    the remaining keyword args are specific for each method. These can be found with
    %kb method_info
    """
    # 1. get method spec
    nms = NarrativeMethodStore(URLS.narrative_method_store)
    try:
        spec = nms.get_method_spec({'ids': [method_id], 'tag': version})[0]
    except:
        raise

    # 2. reconcile parameters, check that the right ones are there.
    input_vals = dict()
    if not spec.has_key('behavior') or not spec['behavior'].has_key('kb_service_input_mapping'):
        raise Exception("Only good for SDK-made methods!")
    for param in spec['behavior']['kb_service_input_mapping']:
        p_value = None
        p_id = None
        if 'input_parameter' in param:
            p_id = param['input_parameter']
            p_value = kwargs.get(p_id, None)
        elif 'narrative_system_variable' in param:
            p_id = param['narrative_system_variable']
            p_value = get_system_variable(p_id)
        input_vals[p_id] = p_value

    method_name = spec['behavior']['kb_service_method']
    service_name = spec['behavior']['kb_service_name']
    service_ver = spec['behavior']['kb_service_version']
    service_url = spec['behavior']['kb_service_url']
    # 3. set up app structure
    app = {'name': 'App wrapper for method ' + method_id,
           'steps': [{'input_values': [input_vals],
                      'is_long_running': 1,
                      'method_spec_id': method_id,
                      'script': {'has_files': 0, 'method_name': '', 'service_name': ''},
                      'service': {'method_name': method_name,
                                  'service_name': service_name,
                                  'service_url': service_url,
                                  'service_version': service_ver},
                      'step_id': method_id,
                      'type': 'service'}]}
    
    njs = NarrativeJobService(URLS.job_service, token=get_system_variable('token'))
    app_state = njs.run_app(app)
    print "Starting app with the following info:"
    pprint(app_state)
    return KBaseJob(app_state)

def kb_output_widget(widget_name, input_data): """ renders a widget! """ from IPython.display import Javascript from jinja2 import Template import json import uuid import time input_template = """ element.html("
"); require(['kbaseNarrativeOutputCell', '{{widget_name}}'], function() { $('#{{input_id}}').kbaseNarrativeOutputCell({"data": {{input_data}}, "type":"method", "widget": "{{widget_name}}", "cellId": "{{input_id}}", "title": "{{cell_title}}", "time": {{timestamp}} }); }); """ js = Template(input_template).render(input_id=uuid.uuid4(), widget_name=widget_name, input_data=input_data, #json.dumps(input_data), cell_title="Title Goes Here", timestamp=int(round(time.time()*1000))) return Javascript(data=js, lib=None, css=None)

#ws = Workspace('https://ci.kbase.us/services/ws')
#ws.list_objects({'workspaces': [get_system_variable('workspace')], 'type': 'KBaseGenomes.Genome'})

%kb list_data
%kb method_info fba_tools/build_metabolic_model dev

kb_show_widget('kbaseTabTable',
               {'type':'KBaseFBA.FBAModel',
                'ws': 'wjriehl:1456453274563',
                'obj':'Arabidopsis_gapfilled'})

kb_output_widget('kbaseTabTable',
               {'type':'KBaseFBA.FBAModel',
                'ws': 'wjriehl:1456453274563',
                'obj':'yersinia_model'})
%kb method_info fba_tools/build_metabolic_model dev

my_job = kb_run_method("fba_tools/build_metabolic_model",
    version="dev",
    genome_id="Rhodobacter_sphaeroides_2.4.1_KBase",
    fbamodel_output_id="test_rhodo_model3",
    minimum_target_flux=100,
    gapfill_model=0)
my_job.status_detail()['original_app']['steps'][0]['method_spec_id']
%kb list_methods dev
model = %kb get_data yersinia_model
spec = %kb get_method fba_tools/build_metabolic_model dev
pprint(spec['behavior'])

run_method('MsneddonContigFilter/filter_contigs', 
           contigset_id="rhodo_contigs", 
           min_length=100)
my_job.status_detail()
%kb get_method fba_tools/build_metabolic_model dev
a = %kb get_data Phosphate-Phospho-Glycolic-Acid

# Hunk of JSON that gets sent to NJS for running jobs.

import json
x = json.loads('{"steps": [{"service": {"method_name": "filter_contigs", "service_name": "MsneddonContigFilter", "service_url": "", "service_version": "10100999595c9031e51a877a8a278d2e06583f3a"}, "script": {"method_name": "", "service_name": "", "has_files": 0}, "method_spec_id": "MsneddonContigFilter/filter_contigs", "input_values": [{"contigset_id": "rhodo_contigs", "min_length": "100", "workspace": "wjriehl:1456453274563"}], "step_id": "MsneddonContigFilter/filter_contigs", "type": "service", "is_long_running": 1}], "name": "App wrapper for method MsneddonContigFilter/filter_contigs"}')

import time
int(round(time.time()*1000))

# imports. run this first!

from biokbase.NarrativeJobService.Client import NarrativeJobService
from biokbase.narrative.common.url_config import URLS
from biokbase.workspace.client import Workspace
from biokbase.narrative_method_store.client import NarrativeMethodStore
from IPython.core.magic import register_line_magic
import os
import re
import json

def get_system_variable(var):

    Returns a KBase system variable. Just a little wrapper.
    options:
        workspace - returns the KBase workspace name

    """

    elif var == 'token':
        return os.environ.get('KB_AUTH_TOKEN', None)

def kb_run_method(method_id, version="release", **kwargs):

    Runs a method programmatically and returns the running job id.
    ONLY WORKS FOR SDK-created METHODS!
    
    * method_id = the fully qualified method id (you can find these with %kb list_methods)

    the remaining keyword args are specific for each method. These can be found with
    %kb method_info
    """

        spec = nms.get_method_spec({'ids': [method_id], 'tag': version})[0]
    except:
        raise

    # 2. reconcile parameters, check that the right ones are there.
    input_vals = dict()
    if not spec.has_key('behavior') or not spec['behavior'].has_key('kb_service_input_mapping'):
        raise Exception("Only good for SDK-made methods!")
    for param in spec['behavior']['kb_service_input_mapping']:
        p_value = None
        p_id = None
        if 'input_parameter' in param:
            p_id = param['input_parameter']
            p_value = kwargs.get(p_id, None)
        elif 'narrative_system_variable' in param:
            p_id = param['narrative_system_variable']
            p_value = get_system_variable(p_id)
        input_vals[p_id] = p_value

    method_name = spec['behavior']['kb_service_method']
    service_name = spec['behavior']['kb_service_name']
    service_ver = spec['behavior']['kb_service_version']
    service_url = spec['behavior']['kb_service_url']
    # 3. set up app structure
    app = {'name': 'App wrapper for method ' + method_id,
           'steps': [{'input_values': [input_vals],
                      'is_long_running': 1,
                      'method_spec_id': method_id,
                      'script': {'has_files': 0, 'method_name': '', 'service_name': ''},
                      'service': {'method_name': method_name,
                                  'service_name': service_name,
                                  'service_url': service_url,
                                  'service_version': service_ver},
                      'step_id': method_id,
                      'type': 'service'}]}
    
    njs = NarrativeJobService(URLS.job_service, token=get_system_variable('token'))
    app_state = njs.run_app(app)
    print "Starting app with the following info:"
    pprint(app_state)
    return KBaseJob(app_state)

def kb_output_widget(widget_name, input_data): """ renders a widget! """ from IPython.display import Javascript from jinja2 import Template import json import uuid import time input_template = """ element.html("
"); require(['kbaseNarrativeOutputCell', '{{widget_name}}'], function() { $('#{{input_id}}').kbaseNarrativeOutputCell({"data": {{input_data}}, "type":"method", "widget": "{{widget_name}}", "cellId": "{{input_id}}", "title": "{{cell_title}}", "time": {{timestamp}} }); }); """ js = Template(input_template).render(input_id=uuid.uuid4(), widget_name=widget_name, input_data=input_data, #json.dumps(input_data), cell_title="Title Goes Here", timestamp=int(round(time.time()*1000))) return Javascript(data=js, lib=None, css=None)

                'ws': 'wjriehl:1456453274563',

markdown: ![KBase Logo](http://kbase.us/wp-content/uploads/2014/11/kbase-logo-web.png) Welcome to the Narrative Interface! === What's a Narrative? --- Design and carry out collaborative computational experiments while creating Narratives: interactive, shareable, and reproducible records of your data, computational steps, and thought processes. learn more... Get Some Data --- Click the Add Data button in the Data Panel to browse for KBase data or upload your own. Mouse over a data object to add it to your Narrative, and check out more details once the data appears in your list. learn more... Analyze It --- Browse available analyses that can be run using KBase apps or methods (apps are just multi-step methods that make some common analyses more convenient). Select an analysis, fill in the fields, and click Run. Output will be generated, and new data objects will be created and added to your data list. Add to your results by running follow-on apps or methods. learn more... Save and Share Your Narrative --- Be sure to save your Narrative frequently. When you're ready, click the share button above to let collaborators view your analysis steps and results. Or better yet, make your Narrative public and help expand the social web that KBase is building to make systems biology research open, collaborative, and more effective. learn more... Find Documentation and Help --- For more information, please see the Narrative Interface User Guide or the app/method tutorials. Questions? Contact us! Ready to begin adding to your Narrative? You can keep this Welcome cell or delete it with the trash icon in the top right corner.

markdown: # Narrative Widget API Demo ## This will show: 1. How to load the widget manager class 2. How to browse for available widgets 3. How to load widgets to view a few different things 4. How to load a widget that uses the mockup CDN **(as of 4/19/2016 this is ONLY available on narrative-dev, or you can install it locally from the `vis-cell-refactor` branch of the Narrative repo)**
code:
# Step 1 - load an instance of the widget manager

from biokbase.narrative.widgetmanager import WidgetManager
wm = WidgetManager()

# Step 2 - list available widgets by name
wm.widget_info['release'].keys()

# Step 3 - show a widgets inputs
wm.print_widget_inputs('kbaseGenomeView')

# Step 4 - view the widget
wm.show_output_widget('kbaseGenomeView', id="Rhodobacter_CACIA_14H1")

# Step 5 - demo a CDN-based widget
wm.show_external_widget('contigSet', 'My ContigSet View', {'objectRef': '6402/3/8'}, {})

# Step 6 - show a CDN-based widget with version selection
wm.show_external_widget(['widgets', '0.1.0', 'genomeComparison'], 'Genome Comparison Demo',
               {'objectRef': '6402/5/2'}, {}, auth_required=True)

# Documentation viewer
wm.show_output_widget?
data.title: Widget API Demo

import doekbase.data_api
from doekbase.data_api.annotation.genome_annotation.api import GenomeAnnotationAPI, GenomeAnnotationClientAPI
from doekbase.data_api.sequence.assembly.api import AssemblyAPI, AssemblyClientAPI
import os
import datetime

ensembl_ws = "ReferenceEnsemblPlantGenomeAnnotations"
algae_ref = "280699_Ensembl"
arabidopsis_ref = "3702_Ensembl"

def generate_data_files_without_client_api(ref, id):
    ga = GenomeAnnotationAPI(internal_services, 
                             token=os.environ.get("KB_AUTH_TOKEN"),
                             ref=ref)
    print "Requesting GenomeAnnotation GFF for {}".format(id)
    gff_start = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    with open('{}.gff'.format(id), 'w') as gff_file:
        ga.get_gff().to_file(gff_file)
    gff_end = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    print "Generating GFF for {} took {}".format(id, gff_end - gff_start)

    print "Requesting Assembly FASTA for {}".format(id)
    fasta_start = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    with open('{}.fasta'.format(id), 'w') as fasta_file:
        ga.get_assembly().get_fasta().to_file(fasta_file)
    fasta_end = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    print "Generating FASTA for {} took {}".format(id, fasta_end - fasta_start)

def generate_gff_with_client_api(ref, id):
    ga = GenomeAnnotationClientAPI(data_api_services["genome_annotation"], 
                                   token=os.environ.get("KB_AUTH_TOKEN"),
                                   ref=ref)
    print "Requesting GenomeAnnotation GFF for {}".format(id)
    gff_start = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    with open('{}.gff'.format(id), 'w') as gff_file:
        ga.get_gff().to_file(gff_file)
    gff_end = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    print "Generating GFF for {} took {}".format(id, gff_end - gff_start)
    
    #with open('{}.fasta'.format(id), 'w') as fasta_file:
    #    assembly = AssemblyClientAPI(data_api_services["assembly"],
    #                                 token=os.environ.get("KB_AUTH_TOKEN"),
    #                                 ref=ga.get_assembly())
    #    assembly.get_fasta().to_file(fasta_file)

%rm *
%ls -lh

for id in [algae_ref, arabidopsis_ref]:
    generate_data_files_without_client_api("{}/{}".format(ensembl_ws, id), id)

%ls -lh

print "\n\n\n"

%rm *
%ls -lh

for id in [algae_ref, arabidopsis_ref]:
    generate_gff_with_client_api("{}/{}".format(ensembl_ws, id), id)

%ls -lh

import doekbase.data_api
from doekbase.data_api.annotation.genome_annotation.api import GenomeAnnotationAPI, GenomeAnnotationClientAPI
from doekbase.data_api.sequence.assembly.api import AssemblyAPI, AssemblyClientAPI
import os
import datetime

ensembl_ws = "ReferenceEnsemblPlantGenomeAnnotations"
algae_ref = "280699_Ensembl"
arabidopsis_ref = "3702_Ensembl"

def generate_data_files_without_client_api(ref, id):
    ga = GenomeAnnotationAPI(internal_services, 
                             token=os.environ.get("KB_AUTH_TOKEN"),
                             ref=ref)
    print "Requesting GenomeAnnotation GFF for {}".format(id)
    gff_start = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    with open('{}.gff'.format(id), 'w') as gff_file:
        ga.get_gff().to_file(gff_file)
    gff_end = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    print "Generating GFF for {} took {}".format(id, gff_end - gff_start)

    print "Requesting Assembly FASTA for {}".format(id)
    fasta_start = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    with open('{}.fasta'.format(id), 'w') as fasta_file:
        ga.get_assembly().get_fasta().to_file(fasta_file)
    fasta_end = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    print "Generating FASTA for {} took {}".format(id, fasta_end - fasta_start)

def generate_gff_with_client_api(ref, id):
    ga = GenomeAnnotationClientAPI(data_api_services["genome_annotation"], 
                                   token=os.environ.get("KB_AUTH_TOKEN"),
                                   ref=ref)
    print "Requesting GenomeAnnotation GFF for {}".format(id)
    gff_start = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    with open('{}.gff'.format(id), 'w') as gff_file:
        ga.get_gff().to_file(gff_file)
    gff_end = datetime.datetime.utcnow()
    print "Generating GFF for {} took {}".format(id, gff_end - gff_start)
    
    #with open('{}.fasta'.format(id), 'w') as fasta_file:
    #    assembly = AssemblyClientAPI(data_api_services["assembly"],
    #                                 token=os.environ.get("KB_AUTH_TOKEN"),
    #                                 ref=ga.get_assembly())
    #    assembly.get_fasta().to_file(fasta_file)

%rm *
%ls -lh

for id in [algae_ref, arabidopsis_ref]:
    generate_data_files_without_client_api("{}/{}".format(ensembl_ws, id), id)

%ls -lh

print "\n\n\n"

%rm *
%ls -lh

for id in [algae_ref, arabidopsis_ref]:
    generate_gff_with_client_api("{}/{}".format(ensembl_ws, id), id)

%ls -lh

code:
from biokbase.narrative.jobs.jobmanager import JobManager
from biokbase.narrative.jobs.methodmanager import MethodManager
jm = JobManager()
mm = MethodManager()
mm.list_available_methods(tag='dev')
mm.method_description('NarrativeTest/test_input_params', tag='dev')
mm.method_usage('NarrativeTest/test_input_params', tag='dev')

my_job = mm.run_method('NarrativeTest/test_input_params', 
                       tag='dev', 
                       actual_input_object="my_other_new_genome",
                       actual_output_object="new_genome_2")
my_job.info()
jm.list_jobs()
my_job.info()
my_job.output_viewer()

my_job = jm.get_job('57320ecee4b0f08f9eb97e03')
my_job.info()
data.title: Narrative/Jupyter Cell Standardization Demo

# Method Cell Refactor

First, it is now the **App Cell**

## TODO:

- app cell needs to be collapsible
- it also previously had cool summary info when collapsed
- output cell needs title.
- <del>tamp down the events which cause proliferation of narrative versions.</del>
- wish there was a way to trim old versions...
- add collapsible configuration panel, and default to the fancy stuff turned off.
- ensure that the errors are handled better
- log - finish, esp. paging
- only show buttons which are relevant to the current state -- use the fsm config to do this
- automatically created (or those created with some setting) channels will be closed and removed after there are no more listeners.
- sub-widgets need to be reset (or just removed and re-added), they sometimes show a flash of stale information when re-opened
- inputs which render only after fetching data -- make better -- either take data from the data panel or show a spinner.

markdown:
# Method Cell Refactor

First, it is now the **App Cell**

## TODO:

- app cell needs to be collapsible
- it also previously had cool summary info when collapsed
- output cell needs title.
- <del>tamp down the events which cause proliferation of narrative versions.</del>
- wish there was a way to trim old versions...
- add collapsible configuration panel, and default to the fancy stuff turned off.
- ensure that the errors are handled better
- log - finish, esp. paging
- only show buttons which are relevant to the current state -- use the fsm config to do this
- automatically created (or those created with some setting) channels will be closed and removed after there are no more listeners.
- sub-widgets need to be reset (or just removed and re-added), they sometimes show a flash of stale information when re-opened
- inputs which render only after fetching data -- make better -- either take data from the data panel or show a spinner.

markdown:
# Reconciling genome annotations with Gene Ontology (GO) The Gene Ontology (GO) project is a major bioinformatics initiative to develop a computational representation of our evolving knowledge of how genes encode biological functions at the molecular, cellular and tissue system levels. The project has developed formal ontologies that represent over 40,000 biological concepts, and are constantly being revised to reflect new discoveries. ## Summary: KBase has implemented methods that allow to reconcile different sources of annotation with GO terms. In this study we aim to reconcile annotations for Shewanella oneidensis MR-1. ### Annotation sources: * GenBank annotation from NCBI:http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/genome/1082 * UniProt annotation from UniProt: http://www.uniprot.org/taxonomy/211586 * KBase annotation, using "Annotate Microbial Genome" to re-annotate GenBank genome * InterPro annotation, "Remap Annotations with InterPro2GO" implements the full Interpro pipeline to re-annotate the GenBank genome and map the resulting annotations to GO terms. ### Remap to GO methods: * Remap Annotations with EC2GO. Enzyme Commission numbers mappings to GO terms. * Remap Annotations with UniProtKB-Keyword2GO. Keywords are mapped to corresponding GO terms in the UniProtKB. * Remap Annotations with InterPro2GO. Interpro is an integrated resource of protein families, domains and sites which are combined from a number of different protein signature databases, including. Gene3D, Panther, PRSF, Pfam, PRINTS, ProSite, ProDom, SMART, SUPERFAMILY and TIGRFAMs. * Remap annotations based on Ontology translation table allows use of custom translation tables, used for SEED2GO mapping for the recently introduced SEED Subsystem Ontology (developed during the current campaign) Translation tables from: http://www.ebi.ac.uk/GOA/ElectronicAnnotationMethods ### Results:

#### NOTES: * We have performed EC2GO mappings for 3 annotation sources (GenBank, KBase and Uniprot), because EC numbers are commonly included in annotation descriptions. * We performed UniProtKB-Keyword2GO for GenBank and Uniprot annotation souces, because these particular sources use similar protein naming conventions * We only performed SEED2GO mapping on the KBase genome since its the only one annotated with RAST/SEED functional annotations * The remap annotations to interpro2go runs the full interpro pipeline and performs conversion to GO terms, thus we only used this mappings method for this annotation source. ### Conclusions: * Interpro2GO re-annotation and mapping to GO terms mapped the highest number of annotations, a total of 2642 in the Shewanella genome to GO terms. * The higher number of mappings for InterPro2GO comes at a price, as the full method took ~15 hours to run. * The very similar number in UniProtKB-Keyword2Go mappings for the GenBank and UniProt annotations confirms that they indeed use similar protein naming conventions. GenBank genome though lacks EC numbers in its annotations descriptions when compared to the Uniprot genome. * The mappings on the KBase genome yielded a higher number of mappings when using EC2GO. * (Pending improvements to Genome Comparison Widget, details bellow) To which extent all the methods map the same go-terms to the same genes? ### Improvements to Ontology services: * Mixed use of annotations from different ontology translations in our output genomes substantially complicates the analysis. Adding of a checkbox to “remap” functions to optionally wipe away existing annotations, so then the only annotations you’ll have will all be GO annotations. This would make comparison far easier. * Looking at our results, we should merge unitprot2go and ec2go functions. Combining these together into a single function “Remap annotations using uniprot2go and ec2go” as both methods produce a small number of non-overlapping mappings. The combined function would let you choose which translation mechanisms to apply with a dropdown with the options: ec2go only; uniprot2go only; both. #### Improvements to Genome Comparison Widget that impact ontology comparison: * Being able to see which ontology, each function in the comparison came from. Adding this information to the genome comparison method and data type itself is a possibility to tackle this issue. * Being able to click on a function and have a more detailed tab come up, including containing details on the ontology term itself. * Maybe better visualizations? Maybe have comparison of functions broken down by ontology?

### Step 1: Load a genome from GenBank and UniProt
In this study we aim to reconcillie different annotation of Shewanella oneidensis MR-1 by mapping descriptions of functional annotations to GO terms. For this purpose we first load genome annotations from GenBank (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/) and UniProt (http://www.uniprot.org/) using the KBase Genome Uploader.

### Step 2: Re-annotate GenBank genome with KBase's Annotate Microbial Genome (RAST)
In addtion to GenBank and UniProt annotations we also to re-annotated the GenBank genome we uploaded on KBase we use the method "RASTtk - Annotate Microbial Genome". This method allows us to keep the original gene calls, only replacing functional roles with RAST/SEED annotations.

RASTtk - Annotate Microbial Genome

Parameters:

  • Call features strep suis repeat - 0

  • Call selenoproteins - 0

  • Call features crispr - 0

  • Call features insertion sequences - 0
