  • Call features CDS glimmer3 - 0
  • Genome - Shew_GenBank
  • Call features repeat region SEED - 0
  • Call features prophage phispy - 0

Suggested Replacements:
The following replacement apps might help and are available in the Apps menu:
  • Annotate Microbial Genome

### Step 3: Re-annotate GenBank genome with Interpro and convert annotations to GO terms
Intrpro is an integrated resource of protein families, domains and sites which are combined from a number of different protein signature databases, including. Gene3D, Panther, PRSF, Pfam, PRINTS, ProSite, ProDom, SMART, SUPERFAMILY and TIGRFAMs."Remap Annotations with InterPro2GO" implements the full Interpro pipeline to re-annotate the GenBank genome and map the resulting annotations to GO terms.
We now have 4 genomes annotations souces: GenBank, UniProt, KBase and Interpro; but only the Interpro annotations have been mapped to GO terms.

### Step 4: Load Ontology Translation Tables
Ontology translation tables regularly updated and maintained by the community are available here: http://www.ebi.ac.uk/GOA/ElectronicAnnotationMethods. We loaded ontology translation tables using the "Ontology Translation" uploader to aid in the mapping of annotations to GO terms for the remaining annotations sources.
Enzyme Comission to GO (EC2GO)
InterPro to GO (InterPro2GO)
SEED Subsystem Ontology to GO (SEED2GO)
UniProt Knowledgebase to GO (UniProtKB-Keyword2GO)
### Step 5: Translate GenBank genome annotations to GO terms

### 5.1: Translate GenBank Genome with EC2GO

In order to remap the GenBank annotation to GO terms we firt attempt to map EC numbers in the annotation descriptions to GO terms using "Remap Annotations with EC2GO".
It appears the GenBank annotation do not included EC numbers.

### 5.2: Translate GenBank Genome with UniProtKB-Keyword2GO

The NCBI's Prokaryotic Genome Annotation pipeline states in its standards that protein naming conventions are adopted in part from the UniProt-Swiss-Prot Protein Knowledgebase. We thus attemp to translate protein names to GO terms using "Remap Annotations with UniProKB-Keyword2GO"
A total of 1688 features annotations were mapped to GO terms.
### Step 6: Translate KBase annotated genome to GO termsÂś

### 6.1: Translate KBase Genome with EC2GO

KBase annotated genomes with the RAST pipeline include EC numbers in their annotation descriptions. We thus proceed to use "Remap Annotations with EC2GO" to map annotations to GO terms.
A total of 864 features annotations were mapped to GO terms.

### 6.2: Translate KBase Genome with SEED2GO
KBase annoatated genomes are annotated with RAST. Here use the recent developed SEED/RAST ontology translation table to map annoatations to GO terms.

## PLEASE READ
Shew_RAST = Shew_Re_annoatated
There is probably some issue with the SEED2GO on the new generic translation widget. As seen bellow, new widget maps 15 features, old one maps 515.
A total of 515 features annotations were converted to GO terms.
### Step 7: Translate UniProt annotated genome to GO terms

### 7.1: Translate UniProt Genome with UniProtKB-Keyword2GO

To translate the UniProt annotated genome we uploaded we use "Remap Annotations with UniProKB-Keyword2GO"
A total of 1690 features annotations were converted to GO terms.

### 7.2: Translate UniProt Genome with EC2GO

As Uniprot annotations also include EC numbers we use "Remap Annotations with EC2GO" to compare mappings to GO terms vs using UniprotKB-Keyword2GO
As expected we have an lower number of mappings to GO terms (958) with using this method.

### Step 8: Compute Pangenome for 4 sources of annotations translated to GO terms
For annotation sources for which we performed more than one mapping to GO terms, we chose the one with a higher number of mapped GO terms. KBase's "Compute Pangenome" allows to convert the 4 different souces of annotations into a pangenome.
### Step 9: Compare Genomes from Pangenome

The last step is to compare the genomes from pangenome using "Compare Genomes from Pangenome". This comparison allows to understand to which extent all the methods map the same go-terms to the same genes.

Compare Genomes from Pangenome

Parameters:
  • Pangenome - Shew_annotations2GO
  • Genome Comparison - Shew_annotations2GO_Comparison

Suggested Replacements:
The following replacement apps might help and are available in the Apps menu:

data.title: Reconciling genome annotations with Gene Ontology (GO) in KBase

# Reconciling genome annotations with Gene Ontology (GO) The Gene Ontology (GO) project is a major bioinformatics initiative to develop a computational representation of our evolving knowledge of how genes encode biological functions at the molecular, cellular and tissue system levels. The project has developed formal ontologies that represent over 40,000 biological concepts, and are constantly being revised to reflect new discoveries. ## Summary: KBase has implemented methods that allow to reconcile different sources of annotation with GO terms. In this study we aim to reconcile annotations for Shewanella oneidensis MR-1. ### Annotation sources: * GenBank annotation from NCBI:http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/genome/1082 * UniProt annotation from UniProt: http://www.uniprot.org/taxonomy/211586 * KBase annotation, using "Annotate Microbial Genome" to re-annotate GenBank genome * InterPro annotation, "Remap Annotations with InterPro2GO" implements the full Interpro pipeline to re-annotate the GenBank genome and map the resulting annotations to GO terms. ### Remap to GO methods: * Remap Annotations with EC2GO. Enzyme Commission numbers mappings to GO terms. * Remap Annotations with UniProtKB-Keyword2GO. Keywords are mapped to corresponding GO terms in the UniProtKB. * Remap Annotations with InterPro2GO. Interpro is an integrated resource of protein families, domains and sites which are combined from a number of different protein signature databases, including. Gene3D, Panther, PRSF, Pfam, PRINTS, ProSite, ProDom, SMART, SUPERFAMILY and TIGRFAMs. * Remap annotations based on Ontology translation table allows use of custom translation tables, used for SEED2GO mapping for the recently introduced SEED Subsystem Ontology (developed during the current campaign) Translation tables from: http://www.ebi.ac.uk/GOA/ElectronicAnnotationMethods ### Results:

GenBank genome though lacks EC numbers in its annotations descriptions when compared to the Uniprot genome. * The mappings on the KBase genome yielded a higher number of mappings when using EC2GO. * (Pending improvements to Genome Comparison Widget, details bellow) To which extent all the methods map the same go-terms to the same genes? ### Improvements to Ontology services: * Mixed use of annotations from different ontology translations in our output genomes substantially complicates the analysis.
